Clinical Pearls

- Hyperorality (e.g., binge eating, sweet cravings) is a red flag for bvFTD.
• Early executive dysfunction with relative sparing of memory distinguishes bvFTD from Alzheimer’s.
• SSRIs can ameliorate disinhibition and compulsivity in bvFTD; disease-modifying therapies remain investigational.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on memory loss: Students often assume memory impairment is the earliest feature in all dementias, delaying FTD recognition.
2. Misinterpreting weight gain or eating changes as depression or medication side effects rather than orbitofrontal involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Frontotemporal Dementia Consortium (Rascovsky et al., Brain 2011):
• Recommendation: Use revised consensus criteria for possible/probable bvFTD—requires ≥3 core features plus imaging support.
• Level of evidence: Class I diagnostic accuracy study.
2. Boxer AL et al. (Neurology 2013): Randomized placebo-controlled trial of memantine in bvFTD
• Finding: No significant benefit on cognitive or behavioral scales.
• Level of evidence: Class I therapeutic trial, memantine not recommended.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Orbitofrontal cortex degeneration → disinhibition, hyperorality.
• Anterior cingulate involvement → apathy/inertia.
• Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex → executive dysfunction, planning deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Tauopathies (e.g., Pick disease) feature intraneuronal Pick bodies; mutations in MAPT gene in familial cases.
• TDP-43 proteinopathies (GRN, C9orf72 expansions) lead to cytoplasmic inclusions and selective neuronal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history focusing on behavior, dietary changes, social conduct.
2. Neuropsychological testing emphasizing executive function vs memory.
3. Structural MRI: assess for frontal/anterior temporal atrophy.
4. Functional imaging (FDG-PET/SPECT) if MRI equivocal—look for hypometabolism.
5. Genetic testing if family history positive (MAPT, GRN, C9orf72).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: asymmetrical frontal or temporal lobe atrophy early in bvFTD.
• FDG-PET: frontal hypometabolism with relative posterior sparing distinguishes bvFTD from AD.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No FDA-approved disease-modifying agents.
• SSRIs (e.g., sertraline 50–100 mg/day) often reduce disinhibition and compulsivity (Level B evidence).
• Atypical antipsychotics reserved for severe agitation, used cautiously due to adverse effects.

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) is characterized by an objective decline in one or more cognitive domains greater than expected for age and education, yet patients maintain independence in both instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs) and basic ADLs. Dementia (major neurocognitive disorder in DSM-5) requires deficits in at least two cognitive domains that substantially interfere with independence in everyday activities. Key clinical distinctions hinge on functional impact: IADLs include managing finances, medication, and transportation, while basic ADLs cover feeding, dressing, and bathing. Normal age-related memory loss involves benign, nonprogressive lapses without functional decline. Delirium is acute, fluctuating inattention with altered consciousness, usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated.

Evidence-Based Analysis

According to DSM-5 (American Psychiatric Association, 2013), major neurocognitive disorder is diagnosed when cognitive deficits in ≥2 domains significantly impair independence in everyday activities—here evidenced by the patient’s inability to manage his ATM card without assistance. The 2011 NIA-AA criteria for Alzheimer’s disease emphasize functional decline beyond normal aging as a hallmark of dementia rather than MCI. Petersen et al. (2014) demonstrated that impairment of IADLs (e.g., financial management) distinguishes MCI from early dementia with >80% sensitivity. Although occupational performance may remain intact initially, loss of autonomy in home-based IADLs confirms a diagnosis of dementia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
• Incorrect because MCI patients preserve independence in all IADLs and basic ADLs.
• Misconception: Any measurable memory decline equals MCI.
• Key differentiator: No functional impairment.

C. Normal age-related memory loss
• Incorrect because benign aging does not lead to persistent or progressive functional impairment.
• Misconception: Attributing any daily-life mishap to normal aging.
• Key differentiator: Lack of progressive decline or interference with ADLs/IADLs.

D. Delirium
• Incorrect because delirium is acute (hours–days), with fluctuating attention and altered consciousness.
• Misconception: Equating chronic memory issues with delirium.
• Key differentiator: Disturbance in attention and level of consciousness, plus reversibility.

Clinical Pearls

- Distinguish IADLs (e.g., managing finances) from basic ADLs; early dementia often first impairs IADLs.
• Annual conversion rate from MCI to dementia is ~10–15%; monitor IADLs with standardized scales (e.g., Lawton IADL).
• Use brief cognitive screens (MoCA, MMSE) alongside caregiver reports of functional decline for early detection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Interpreting a single workplace success as ruling out dementia—functional decline often occurs first in home IADLs.
• Attributing any memory lapse in an older adult to “normal aging” without assessing impact on daily living.
• Confusing delirium with dementia by focusing on memory rather than attention, consciousness, and onset.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 Practice Guideline on MCI: Recommends standardized IADL assessments to differentiate MCI from dementia (Level B evidence).
• NICE Guideline NG97 (2018 update): Defines dementia diagnosis by cognitive impairment plus functional decline; endorses IADL/basic ADL scales and caregiver questionnaires (moderate-quality evidence).

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is a primary neurodegenerative disorder in the α-synucleinopathy spectrum. Pathologically, it is defined by Lewy bodies—eosinophilic intraneuronal inclusions rich in misfolded α-synuclein—affecting cortical and subcortical structures. Clinically, DLB is distinguished from Alzheimer’s disease (AD) by early impairments in visuospatial processing, attention, and executive function rather than memory and language, and from vascular dementia by the absence of stepwise decline or focal deficits. Per the 2017 DLB Consortium criteria, core features include fluctuating cognition, recurrent visual hallucinations, and spontaneous parkinsonism. These distinctions guide diagnostic workup (including dopamine transporter imaging) and management, particularly around cholinergic therapy and antipsychotic sensitivity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: DLB typically presents with recurrent, well-formed visual hallucinations and pronounced fluctuations in cognition and alertness, often daily. McKeith et al.’s 2017 revised consensus criteria (Neurology 2017;89:88–100) classify visual hallucinations and cognitive fluctuations as core features with high sensitivity and specificity (~80–90%). Pathophysiologically, cortical α-synuclein deposition and severe cholinergic deficits underlie neuropsychiatric symptoms, while nigrostriatal involvement produces parkinsonism. Dopamine transporter SPECT shows reduced striatal uptake, a supportive biomarker. Clinical guidelines (e.g., NICE NG97, 2018) recommend rivastigmine for cognitive and behavioral symptoms (Level B evidence) and warn against typical antipsychotics due to neuroleptic sensitivity. Thus, B aligns precisely with established diagnostic hallmarks and management principles.

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option A: “Characterized by early memory loss and language deficits.”
• Incorrect: Early episodic memory and language involvement are hallmarks of AD, not DLB.
• Misconception: Equating all dementias with AD-like amnestic presentations.
• Differentiation: DLB shows visuospatial and attentional decline before memory and relatively preserved naming.

Option C: “Is primarily caused by vascular pathology.”
• Incorrect: Vascular dementia arises from cumulative ischemic injury; DLB is an α-synucleinopathy.
• Misconception: Attributing any dementia with parkinsonism to vascular causes.
• Differentiation: Vascular dementia has stepwise progression, focal deficits, and MRI evidence of infarcts.

Option D: “Does not involve parkinsonism features.”
• Incorrect: Spontaneous parkinsonian signs (rigidity, bradykinesia) are a core diagnostic criterion for DLB.
• Misconception: Believing parkinsonism only occurs in Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD).
• Differentiation: In DLB, parkinsonism appears early or concomitantly, whereas PDD requires dementia onset >1 year after motor symptoms.

Clinical Pearls

• REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) often precedes cognitive symptoms by years in DLB; ask specifically about dream enactment.
• DLB patients are exquisitely sensitive to typical antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol); use rivastigmine and, if needed, low-dose atypical agents with caution.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking early hallucinations in DLB for psychosis or delirium rather than a neurodegenerative sign.
• Over-relying on memory tests alone and overlooking visuospatial/executive deficits that distinguish DLB from AD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- McKeith IG et al., “Diagnosis and management of DLB,” Neurology 2017:89:88–100. Revised consensus criteria define core features (visual hallucinations, fluctuations, parkinsonism) and incorporate dopamine transporter imaging as Level II biomarker.
• NICE Guideline NG97, 2018 (UK): Recommends rivastigmine for symptomatic treatment of cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms in DLB (Evidence level B); advises against typical antipsychotics due to neuroleptic sensitivity.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Lewy bodies accumulate in neocortex (visual association areas), limbic structures, substantia nigra, and locus coeruleus.
• Nigrostriatal involvement explains parkinsonism; cholinergic nucleus basalis of Meynert degeneration underlies attention and visuospatial deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Misfolded α-synuclein aggregates form Lewy bodies → disrupt synaptic function.
• Widespread cholinergic neuronal loss → prominent neuropsychiatric and cognitive fluctuations.
• Dopaminergic depletion in striatum → rigidity and bradykinesia.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Dopamine transporter SPECT (e.g., ^123I-FP-CIT) shows reduced striatal uptake, supporting DLB diagnosis.
• ^123I-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy may show reduced cardiac innervation, a supportive biomarker per 2017 criteria.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Rivastigmine (transdermal or oral) improves cognition and neuropsychiatric symptoms; start low and titrate per tolerability.
• Avoid haloperidol; if antipsychotic required, consider quetiapine or clozapine at minimal effective dose.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) occupies the clinical space between expected age‐related cognitive decline and dementia; patients have objective deficits in one or more domains but preserved activities of daily living.
• Early synaptic dysfunction and hippocampal atrophy underlie the memory impairment in amnestic MCI, while vascular and metabolic factors exacerbate decline.
• Enhancing neuroplasticity through cognitive exercises and improving cerebral perfusion via lifestyle factors (e.g., aerobic activity, dietary modification) form the cornerstone of MCI management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Non‐pharmacologic interventions are first‐line in MCI. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology guideline on MCI (Level B evidence) endorses structured cognitive training and lifestyle modification—such as combined aerobic/resistance exercise and Mediterranean‐style diet—to slow decline. The ACTIVE trial demonstrated that targeted cognitive interventions produced sustained memory benefits and reduced progression to dementia over 5 years. Aerobic exercise RCTs have shown preservation of hippocampal volume (Erickson et al., 2011) and improvement in executive function. By contrast, cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., rivastigmine) and memantine fail to demonstrate efficacy in MCI populations and carry potential adverse effects; high‐dose vitamin E has not shown benefit and may increase hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Rivastigmine
• No RCT in MCI shows delay in conversion to Alzheimer’s dementia (Petersen et al., 2005).
• Misconception: Early cholinergic boost prevents neurodegeneration.
• Differentiator: Approved only for mild‐to‐moderate Alzheimer’s dementia.

B. High dose Vitamin E
• Lacks trial evidence in MCI; Alzheimer’s trials found no cognitive protection and a signal for increased all‐cause mortality/hemorrhagic stroke.
• Misconception: Antioxidants are universally neuroprotective.
• Differentiator: Not disease‐modifying in early cognitive impairment.

D. Memantine
• Studied in moderate‐to‐severe Alzheimer’s dementia only; no data support use in MCI.
• Misconception: NMDA antagonism benefits early synaptic dysfunction.
• Differentiator: Indicated for moderate‐to‐severe stages, not MCI.

Clinical Pearls

- Annual monitoring with standardized cognitive tests (e.g., MoCA, neuropsych battery) is essential to detect progression.
• Multi‐domain lifestyle interventions (diet, exercise, cognitive tasks, social engagement) have synergistic effects on slowing decline.
• Cardiovascular risk factor control (BP, lipids, glycemic management) is a modifiable contributor to MCI progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Initiating cholinesterase inhibitors in MCI despite lack of efficacy data exposes patients to side effects without benefit.
• Misclassifying normal age‐related forgetfulness as MCI can lead to unnecessary interventions.
• Overreliance on supplements (e.g., vitamin E) distracts from evidence‐based lifestyle approaches.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology, 2018: “Mild Cognitive Impairment: Diagnosis and Management.” Recommends cognitive training and exercise; advises against cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine (Level B evidence).
• Lancet Commission on Dementia Prevention, Intervention, and Care, 2020: Endorses multi‐domain lifestyle interventions (exercise, diet, cognitive engagement) to reduce risk of progression from MCI (Expert consensus).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In MCI, early amyloid‐β deposition and tau pathology in hippocampal and entorhinal cortex neurons lead to synaptic loss. Microvascular endothelial dysfunction and oxidative stress exacerbate neuronal injury, tipping the balance toward cognitive decline.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history and mental status exam to confirm subjective cognitive complaints and preserved ADLs.
2. Neuropsychological testing to quantify domain‐specific deficits.
3. Laboratory evaluation (TSH, B12, RPR) to exclude reversible causes.
4. MRI brain to assess hippocampal atrophy or white matter lesions.
5. Implement non‐pharmacologic management and schedule regular follow‐up every 6–12 months.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Volumetric MRI in amnestic MCI often reveals mild bilateral hippocampal atrophy; PET amyloid imaging may stratify risk but is not routinely indicated for standard MCI management.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No pharmacologic agents are FDA‐approved for MCI. Off‐label use of cholinesterase inhibitors or memantine is unsupported by high‐quality evidence and may produce cholinergic or neuropsychiatric adverse effects.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Dementia in Parkinson’s disease (PDD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) arises from α-synuclein deposition in cortical and subcortical structures, notably causing loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert. This cholinergic deficit underlies cognitive decline, attention disturbances, and visual hallucinations. Rivastigmine is a dual cholinesterase inhibitor that enhances synaptic acetylcholine, improving cognition and behavioral symptoms in PDD/DLB. In contrast, memantine targets glutamatergic NMDA receptors, and donepezil selectively inhibits acetylcholinesterase but has less robust evidence in PDD. Lifestyle modifications (exercise, cognitive rehabilitation) are supportive but insufficient as sole therapy in moderate-to-severe dementia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rivastigmine is the only agent with Level A evidence for symptomatic treatment of PDD. In the pivotal randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled multicenter trial by Emre et al. (Lancet Neurol 2004), rivastigmine significantly improved global cognition (MMSE +2.1 vs +0.7 points; p<0.001) and Clinician’s Interview-Based Impression of Change in Severity (CIBIC-Plus) compared to placebo, with an acceptable safety profile. The Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2019 evidence-based review reiterates rivastigmine’s Grade A recommendation for PDD (efficacy and tolerability), endorsing both oral and transdermal formulations to minimize gastrointestinal adverse effects. By contrast, memantine showed only modest, non-significant cognitive benefits in PDD trials (Aarsland et al., 2009), and donepezil, while beneficial in DLB (McKeith et al., 2000), lacks robust, high-level evidence and regulatory approval for PDD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lifestyle modification
• Reason incorrect: Non-pharmacological interventions (exercise, cognitive training) are adjunctive and do not reverse cholinergic deficits in moderate-to-severe PDD.
• Misconception: Believing that lifestyle changes alone can halt neurodegeneration.
• Differentiator: Requires targeted pharmacotherapy (cholinesterase inhibition) for symptomatic cognitive improvement.

C. Memantine
• Reason incorrect: NMDA receptor antagonism has limited efficacy in PDD; major trials did not meet primary endpoints for cognitive improvement.
• Misconception: Extrapolating memantine’s benefit in Alzheimer’s disease to PDD without supporting data.
• Differentiator: Memantine is reserved for moderate-to-severe AD (Level B); rivastigmine has stronger evidence in PDD (Level A).

D. Donepezil
• Reason incorrect: Although donepezil improves cognition in DLB off-label, it is not FDA-approved for PDD and carries only Level B evidence in parkinsonian dementias.
• Misconception: Equating all cholinesterase inhibitors as interchangeable in PDD.
• Differentiator: Rivastigmine’s dual inhibition of acetyl- and butyrylcholinesterase yields superior clinical trial outcomes in PDD.

• Cholinesterase inhibitors can ameliorate visual hallucinations in DLB/PDD by enhancing cortical cholinergic tone.
• Always screen for bradyarrhythmias and peptic ulcer disease before initiating rivastigmine.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing memantine first in PDD, despite lack of robust cognitive benefit trials in this population.
2. Assuming lifestyle interventions suffice for cognitive deficits in moderate-to-severe PDD without cholinesterase inhibition.
3. Treating all dementias with donepezil interchangeably, ignoring specific regulatory approvals and evidence levels.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society Task Force on PDD, 2019: Grade A recommendation for rivastigmine in PDD (Level I randomized trial evidence).
• Dementia with Lewy Bodies Consortium (McKeith et al., 2020): Strong endorsement of rivastigmine for cognitive and behavioral symptoms in DLB (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert and loss of cortical cholinergic projections underlie attentional deficits and visuospatial impairment in PDD/DLB, directly targeted by cholinesterase inhibitors.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

α-Synuclein aggregates form Lewy bodies in cortical and brainstem neurons, disrupting synaptic function. Concurrent cholinergic neuron loss exacerbates cognitive decline and neuropsychiatric features.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Rivastigmine inhibits both acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase, enhancing acetylcholine availability in synaptic clefts. Initiate at low dose (1.5 mg BID or 4.6 mg/24 h patch) and titrate every 4 weeks to balance efficacy and tolerability.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] 1. Pathology: DLB is characterized by cortical α-synuclein Lewy bodies, with particularly severe loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.
2. Neurochemistry: Cholinergic deficits correlate with attentional fluctuations, visuospatial dysfunction, and visual hallucinations.
3. Therapeutic principle: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (AChEIs) augment synaptic acetylcholine, improving cognition and neuropsychiatric symptoms in DLB, often more so than in Alzheimer’s disease.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rivastigmine, a dual acetyl- and butyryl-cholinesterase inhibitor, has demonstrated in multiple randomized controlled trials (e.g., Aarsland et al., Neurology 2004) significant improvements in MMSE scores (mean +1.8 vs placebo; p=0.02) and Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) scores. The 2017 Fourth Consensus Report of the Dementia with Lewy Bodies Consortium (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017) gives a Level A recommendation for rivastigmine in probable DLB. The 2018 NICE guideline NG97 (Dementia: assessment, management and support) also issues a Grade 1 recommendation for rivastigmine in mild-to-moderate DLB, citing systematic reviews of RCTs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Quetiapine
• Mechanism: Dopamine D2/5-HT2 antagonist.
• Why incorrect: Primarily used off-label for psychosis; can worsen parkinsonism and has minimal pro-cognitive effect.
• Misconception: Antipsychotics improve all neuropsychiatric manifestations in DLB.

C. Clonazepam
• Mechanism: GABA-A receptor agonist.
• Why incorrect: First-line for REM sleep behavior disorder in DLB, not cognitive enhancement.
• Misconception: Benzodiazepines broadly benefit neurodegeneration.

D. Pimavanserin
• Mechanism: Selective 5-HT2A inverse agonist.
• Why incorrect: Approved for Parkinson’s psychosis; no evidence for cognitive improvement.
• Misconception: All agents that address hallucinations will also improve cognition.

• Addressing sleep disturbances (e.g., REM sleep behavior disorder) with clonazepam or melatonin may unmask daytime cognitive fluctuations—optimize cholinergic therapy first.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Memory is subdivided into declarative (explicit) and non-declarative (implicit) systems.
• Declarative memory comprises episodic (events, personal experiences) and semantic (facts, concepts) memory, both critically dependent on the hippocampal–diencephalic network (hippocampus, mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nuclei, fornix).
• Korsakoff syndrome, the chronic phase of Wernicke encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency, specifically disrupts episodic encoding and consolidation while sparing procedural (basal ganglia–cerebellar) and short-term/working memory (prefrontal cortex).
• Patients exhibit profound anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and preservation of remote semantic and procedural skills.
(Word count: 108)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Korsakoff dementia results from thiamine-deficiency lesions in the medial dorsal and anterior thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies, disrupting Papez circuit integrity and episodic memory consolidation (Victor et al., 1989; Kopelman, 2002). Clinical studies (Arts et al., 2017) confirm that new event learning (episodic) is the cardinal deficit, whereas immediate recall (span tasks) and working memory remain within normal limits. Procedural memory—skills and habits—uses separate cortico-subcortical circuits (striatum, cerebellum) and is preserved (Fama & Sullivan, 2014). Current practice guidelines (NICE CG100, 2018) emphasize early recognition of Wernicke’s and prophylactic thiamine to prevent progression to Korsakoff’s. MRI morphometry studies (Zuccoli et al., 2023) correlate bilateral mammillary body atrophy with episodic recall impairment (r=0.68, p<0.001). Thus, episodic memory loss is pathognomonic.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Immediate memory
• Incorrect: Immediate (sensory/short-term) span (e.g., digit span) remains intact in Korsakoff’s.
• Misconception: Confusing immediate recall deficits in Alzheimer’s with Korsakoff’s.
• Differentiation: Immediate memory tests phonological loop function, preserved in diencephalic lesions.

C. Working memory
• Incorrect: Working memory (manipulation of held information) relies on dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, not primarily affected by thiamine deficiency.
• Misconception: Equating anterograde amnesia with working memory failure.
• Differentiation: Working memory tasks (e.g., backward digit span) remain near normal.

D. Procedural memory
• Incorrect: Procedural (motor skills, habits) involve basal ganglia/cerebellum circuits and are spared.
• Misconception: Thinking all memory types are globally impaired in dementia.
• Differentiation: Patients can learn new skills (e.g., mirror tracing) despite poor episodic recall.

Clinical Pearls

- Confabulation in Korsakoff’s arises from filling episodic recall gaps; challenging with consistent external cues can reduce false memories.
• Thiamine repletion (500 mg IV TID) at first suspicion of Wernicke’s prevents permanent episodic memory loss.
• Episodic memory testing (e.g., Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test) is more sensitive for diencephalic amnesia than global screens (MMSE).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all dementia syndromes impair working memory; Korsakoff’s spares prefrontal‐mediated working memory.
2. Misattributing procedural learning deficits to Korsakoff’s; skill learning remains intact despite dense anterograde amnesia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NICE Guideline CG100 (2018): Recommends high-dose parenteral thiamine (500 mg IV TID) in suspected Wernicke’s to prevent Korsakoff’s (Level B evidence).
• Zuccoli et al., Journal of Neurology (2023): Prospective MRI study showing mammillary body volume loss predicts episodic memory performance (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the mammillary bodies and anterior/medial dorsal thalamic nuclei interrupt hippocampal outputs via the fornix, selectively abolishing episodic memory encoding while sparing cortico-striatal and prefrontal circuits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thiamine deficiency impairs pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, leading to neuronal energy failure and gliosis in Papez circuit components. Chronic damage produces irreversible episodic anterograde amnesia.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Gerstmann syndrome arises from a focal lesion in the dominant inferior parietal lobule—specifically the angular gyrus (Brodmann area 39). Core features include agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia and left–right disorientation. The angular gyrus also subserves lexical retrieval by integrating visual, somatosensory and semantic networks. When this region is lesioned, patients often exhibit anomic aphasia: fluent speech with intact grammar and comprehension but marked word-finding difficulty. Differentiating aphasia subtypes requires assessment of fluency, comprehension, repetition and naming. In contrast, Wernicke’s aphasia impairs comprehension, transcortical motor aphasia disrupts fluency with preserved repetition, and conduction aphasia selectively impairs repetition with phonemic paraphasias.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anomic aphasia is the hallmark language deficit in Gerstmann syndrome because damage to the angular gyrus disrupts the neural substrate for lexical access without abolishing semantic comprehension or fluency. Geschwind’s disconnection model (1965) first localized naming deficits to BA 39. A voxel-based lesion–symptom mapping study (Pillay et al., Brain 2017) confirmed that lesions restricted to the left angular gyrus produce isolated naming deficits. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 guidelines recommend early comprehensive language screening—including naming tasks—within 24–48 hours of parietal stroke (Class I; Level A). Thus, when Gerstmann’s tetrad co-occurs with fluent speech and intact comprehension, anomic aphasia is the specific language deficit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Wernicke’s aphasia
• Lesion: posterior superior temporal gyrus (BA 22)
• Deficit: impaired comprehension, paragrammatic fluent speech with neologisms
• Misconception: conflating any parietal lesion with receptive aphasia
• Differentiator: anomic aphasia preserves comprehension and has only word-finding pauses

C. Transcortical motor aphasia
• Lesion: anterior superior frontal lobe (watershed of ACA/MCA)
• Deficit: non-fluent speech, intact repetition, mild naming difficulty
• Misconception: all non-fluent disorders arise from parietal damage
• Differentiator: Gerstmann’s patients are fluent and have intact repetition

D. Conduction aphasia
• Lesion: arcuate fasciculus (supramarginal gyrus)
• Deficit: fluent speech, intact comprehension, markedly impaired repetition with phonemic paraphasias
• Misconception: assuming any parietal injury yields repetition deficits
• Differentiator: anomic aphasia shows preserved repetition without phonemic errors

Clinical Pearls

- Gerstmann syndrome’s core tetrad localizes to the dominant angular gyrus; always screen for naming deficits in this context.
• Anomic aphasia is the most common and mildest aphasia; verify naming with standardized tools (e.g., Boston Naming Test).
• Preservation of repetition and comprehension distinguishes anomic from Wernicke’s or conduction aphasias.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking agraphia or acalculia for primary language deficits rather than parietal symbolic dysfunction.
2. Attributing fluent speech in Gerstmann patients to Wernicke’s aphasia; comprehension remains intact in anomic aphasia.
3. Confusing conduction aphasia’s repetition deficit with naming difficulty; conduction has phonemic paraphasias, not pure anomia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (2018): “Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke” recommend comprehensive language screening—especially naming assessments—within 24–48 hours post-stroke (Class I; Level A).
• American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) (2018): Clinical Practice Guideline for Post-Stroke Aphasia endorses targeted lexical retrieval therapy (e.g., semantic feature analysis) for anomic aphasia (Strong Recommendation; Evidence Level B).
• Fridriksson J et al., JAMA Neurology (2019): Randomized controlled trial demonstrated that anodal transcranial direct current stimulation over left angular gyrus combined with naming therapy significantly improved word-retrieval compared with sham (n=30; Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The angular gyrus (BA 39) lies at the convergence of the superior longitudinal fasciculus and visual, auditory and somatosensory cortices. It is critical for multimodal integration required for calculation, writing and naming.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Lesion-induced disconnection within the inferior parietal lobule disrupts semantic-to-lexical mapping. This spares syntactic formulation (fluent speech) and auditory comprehension pathways but impairs retrieval of lexical items.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On MRI, lesions in the inferior parietal lobule—often due to MCA inferior division infarcts—correlate with Gerstmann’s tetrad and anomic aphasia. Diffusion-weighted imaging localizes acute ischemia in BA 39.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is characterized by progressive impairment of episodic (short-term) memory due to early involvement of the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex. By contrast, remote (long-term) memories are relatively spared until later stages. CSF biomarkers follow the AT(N) framework: reduced Aβ₁₋₄₂ (“A”), elevated phosphorylated tau (“T”), and/or total tau indicating neurodegeneration (“N”). Behavioral symptoms such as depression and social withdrawal often accompany early AD. Recognizing this clinical-biomarker signature distinguishes AD from other dementias that present with prominent behavioral, parkinsonian, or asymmetric cortical features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed clinically by an amnestic presentation plus supportive biomarkers. In this patient:
• Clinical: Predominant short-term memory loss with preserved long-term memory is classic early AD (Dubois et al., 2014).
• CSF: Low Aβ₁₋₄₂ correlates with amyloid plaque deposition; elevated tau reflects neurofibrillary tangle burden (Blennow et al., 2015). The 2018 NIA-AA research framework assigns “A+T+” as biologically definitive for AD (Jack et al., 2018).
• Neuroanatomy: Hippocampal atrophy on imaging (not provided but implied) aligns with medial temporal lobe involvement.
Current guidelines (NIA-AA, 2018) recommend integrating cognitive testing, CSF Aβ₁₋₄₂, p-tau, t-tau, and imaging to confirm AD. This patient’s biomarker profile meets “A+T+” criteria, confirming AD over other dementias.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)
• FTD presents with early personality change, disinhibition or language dysfunction rather than isolated episodic memory loss.
• CSF Aβ₁₋₄₂ is typically normal; tau may be mildly elevated but not in the A+T+ pattern.
• Imaging: frontal or anterior temporal atrophy, not hippocampal-predominant.

C. Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB)
• Core features include fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism; early severe memory loss is less prominent.
• CSF biomarkers: Aβ₁₋₄₂ may be low, but tau is not characteristically elevated; α-synuclein markers and DAT-SPECT are more specific.

D. Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD)
• Presents with asymmetric limb rigidity, apraxia, cortical sensory loss, myoclonus, not isolated memory impairment.
• CSF biomarkers do not follow the A+T+ pattern; imaging shows asymmetric cortical atrophy in frontoparietal regions.

Clinical Pearls

1. Episodic memory decline with preserved remote memories is the hallmark of early AD; semantic memory deteriorates later.
2. CSF Aβ₁₋₄₂ < 550 pg/mL plus elevated p-tau (≥ 60 pg/mL) yields > 85% diagnostic accuracy for AD (Blennow et al., 2015).
3. Depression and apathy may precede overt cognitive decline in AD: screen mood to avoid misdiagnosis of “pseudodementia.”

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking depression-related pseudodementia for AD without biomarker confirmation.
• Assuming that all dementias elevate CSF tau; only AD shows the A+T+ signature.
• Overemphasis on long-term memory when short-term episodic loss is more sensitive for early AD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. NIA-AA Research Framework (Jack et al., 2018): Defines AD biologically by AT(N). Recommendation: Use CSF or PET biomarkers for “A” (amyloid) and “T” (tau). (Level: Expert consensus)
2. International Working Group-2 (IWG-2) Criteria (Dubois et al., 2014): Diagnosis of prodromal and dementia stages of AD requires cognitive symptoms + in vivo biomarkers (CSF Aβ₁₋₄₂ and p-tau). (Level: Expert consensus)
3. Aducanumab (Biogen) EMERGE/ENGAGE trials (2020): Showed dose-dependent amyloid reduction; led to FDA accelerated approval in 2021. (Level: Phase 3)
4. Lecanemab (Clarity AD, 2023): Demonstrated 27% slowing of clinical decline and amyloid clearance on PET. (Level: Phase 3)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

AD initially affects the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex (Brodmann areas 28/34), spreading to parahippocampal gyrus and association cortices. Neurofibrillary tangles follow Braak staging I–II in transentorhinal regions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

The amyloid cascade hypothesis posits accumulation of Aβ₁₋₄₂ oligomers triggers tau hyperphosphorylation, synaptic dysfunction, microglial activation, and neuronal death. CSF reflects these processes: ↓ Aβ (deposition), ↑ p-tau (tangle formation), ↑ t-tau (neuronal injury).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: history of episodic memory loss, functional assessment.
2. Cognitive testing: MMSE, MoCA to quantify deficits.
3. Lab work: rule out reversible causes (B12, TSH, RPR).
4. Neuroimaging: MRI to assess hippocampal atrophy; FDG-PET for temporoparietal hypometabolism.
5. CSF biomarkers: Aβ₁₋₄₂, p-tau, t-tau for AT(N) classification.
6. Confirm diagnosis and stratify stage for management.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• MRI: medial temporal lobe atrophy is the most sensitive volumetric marker for early AD.
• FDG-PET: bilateral posterior cingulate and temporoparietal hypometabolism.
• Amyloid PET (e.g., Florbetapir): visualizes Aβ deposition; positive in preclinical and clinical AD.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine): improve cognition and function in mild–moderate AD (AAN Level A).
• Memantine: NMDA receptor antagonist for moderate–severe AD.
• Disease-modifying: Aducanumab and lecanemab reduce amyloid but require careful ARIA monitoring (MRI every 3–6 months).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Dementias are broadly divided into neurodegenerative (progressive neuronal loss) and secondary (e.g., vascular). The most prevalent neurodegenerative dementia is Alzheimer's disease (AD, ~60–70% of cases). Among purely neurodegenerative causes, Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) follows AD as the second most common (~15–20%), characterized by cortical α-synuclein aggregates. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) accounts for ~5–10%. Vascular dementia represents cerebrovascular injury rather than primary neurodegeneration. Understanding relative frequencies and pathologies underpins accurate diagnosis and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lewy Body Dementia is confirmed at autopsy in approximately 15–20% of dementia cases, making it the second most common neurodegenerative dementia after AD. A meta-analysis by Prince et al. (Lancet Neurol 2013) reported DLB prevalence of 4.2–7.5% in clinical series, but population-based and neuropathology studies (Jellinger & Attems, Acta Neuropathol 2010) show rates up to 20%. The 2017 Fourth DLB Consortium Criteria (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017) emphasize its prevalence and hallmarks (visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, cognitive fluctuations). Vascular dementia (~10–15%) stems from infarcts and is not classified as neurodegenerative. FTD (~5–10%) has tau or TDP-43 pathology but lower frequency. Thus, LBD is the correct choice.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)
• Prevalence: ~5–10% of dementias, less than LBD.
• Misconception: conflating behavioral syndromes with higher frequency; FTD is rarer and presents with early personality changes.

C. Alzheimer's Disease (AD)
• AD is the most common neurodegenerative dementia (~60–70%), not second.
• Misconception: confusing “most common” with “second most common.”

D. Vascular Dementia
• Etiology: cerebrovascular injury, not primary neurodegeneration.
• Although it ranks second overall in some series (~15%), it is classified separately from neurodegenerative dementias.

1. LBD often shows REM sleep behavior disorder years before cognitive decline.
2. Neuroleptic sensitivity is a red flag in suspected LBD.
3. Mixed AD+vascular pathology is common—confirm pure neurodegenerative subtype by clinical hallmarks.

1. Assuming vascular dementia is neurodegenerative; it is due to cerebrovascular insults.
2. Overestimating FTD prevalence because of its dramatic behavioral presentation.

2. Alzheimer’s Disease International, World Alzheimer Report 2021: Global epidemiology data confirming AD (~60%), LBD (~15%), vascular dementia (~15%), FTD (~5%); emphasizes need for subtype-specific diagnostic strategies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Behavioral‐variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) manifests with early changes in personality, social conduct, and executive function due to frontal and anterior temporal lobe degeneration. Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) is categorized by underlying protein deposition (TDP‐43, tau, or FUS) and by specific gene mutations. The most common autosomal dominant genetic cause of bvFTD (often co‐occurring with ALS) is a hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 gene. MAPT mutations lead to tauopathies (FTLD‐tau) and FUS mutations to FTLD‐FUS. Although TDP‐43 protein inclusions are seen in ~50% of FTLD cases, TDP‐43 itself is not the gene defect.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hexanucleotide (GGGGCC) repeat expansions in C9orf72 on chromosome 9p21 account for ~25–40% of familial bvFTD and ~5–10% of sporadic cases (DeJesus‐Hernandez et al., 2011; Renton et al., 2011). Pathogenic repeats cause toxic RNA foci and dipeptide repeat proteins, triggering nucleocytoplasmic transport defects and TDP-43 pathology (FTLD-TDP type B/C). Rascovsky et al.’s 2011 consensus criteria recommend C9orf72 testing in suspected bvFTD, especially with family history or motor neuron signs. While TDP-43 defines the proteinopathy, the gene defect is C9orf72. MAPT and FUS mutations each account for <10% of genetic bvFTD and produce distinct tau or FUS inclusions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. TDP-43
• Reason incorrect: TDP-43 is a pathologic protein inclusion, not the gene mutation.
• Misconception: Equating the hallmark proteinopathy with the causative gene.
• Differentiator: The implicated gene in FTD is TARDBP only in rare ALS cases, not bvFTD.

B. MAPT
• Reason incorrect: MAPT encodes tau; mutations cause FTLD-tau (FTDP-17), often with parkinsonism.
• Misconception: Assuming tau mutations are the most common familial cause.
• Differentiator: MAPT mutations account for ~5–10% of familial FTD and yield tau, not TDP-43, inclusions.

D. FUS
• Reason incorrect: FUS gene mutations underlie a rare FTLD‐FUS subtype and juvenile ALS, <5% of cases.
• Misconception: Overestimating FUS prevalence in bvFTD.
• Differentiator: Clinical presentation often includes early motor neuron features.

1. Misreading TDP-43 pathology as the genetic mutation rather than a downstream protein abnormality.
2. Overprioritizing MAPT mutations; in practice, C9orf72 expansions are the leading cause of familial bvFTD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2021: Recommends offering C9orf72 genetic testing for all bvFTD patients with positive family history or motor neuron signs (Level B).
• DeJesus‐Hernandez et al., 2011 (Nature) & Renton et al., 2011 (Neuron): Landmark studies identifying C9orf72 expansions as a major genetic cause of bvFTD/ALS.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] • Thiamine deficiency injures diencephalic components of the Papez circuit (mammillary bodies, medial dorsal nucleus of thalamus), disrupting hippocampal output.
• Memory systems:
– Working memory (prefrontal cortex; transient manipulation of information).
– Declarative (explicit) memory subdivided into episodic (personal events) and semantic (general facts), both hippocampus-dependent.
– Procedural (implicit) memory (basal ganglia, cerebellum).
• In Korsakoff’s syndrome—the chronic amnestic phase of Wernicke’s encephalopathy—episodic memory is most profoundly impaired, with relative preservation of other domains.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Episodic memory deficits are the hallmark of Korsakoff’s encephalopathy due to targeted destruction of the mammillary bodies and medial dorsal thalamic nuclei—key nodes in the hippocampal–diencephalic memory loop (Papez circuit). Postmortem studies reveal gliosis and neuronal loss in these structures correlating with profound anterograde amnesia, especially for autobiographical events. Clinical neuropsychological assessments consistently demonstrate near-abolition of episodic recall (Reed et al., 2003; Kopelman, 2013). By contrast, semantic memory (general knowledge) and working memory are relatively spared initially because they rely on neocortical and prefrontal circuits less vulnerable to thiamine deficiency. Current consensus guidelines (NICE CG100, 2016; EFNS 2010) focus on prompt thiamine replacement to limit Papez circuit injury but note that once chronic amnesia sets in, episodic memory impairment is often irreversible.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Declarative memory
– Incorrect because “declarative” includes both episodic and semantic memory; only the episodic subset is most severely hit.
– Misconception: conflating broad category with the specific subdomain primarily affected.
– Differentiator: semantic memory often preserved early.
C. Working memory
– Incorrect: working memory depends on dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, which is relatively spared in thiamine deficiency.
– Misconception: equating “short-term memory” with the profound amnesia seen in Korsakoff’s.
– Differentiator: patients can hold and manipulate items (e.g., digit span), despite inability to consolidate into long term.
D. Semantic memory
– Incorrect: although semantic memory eventually declines in advanced cases, it is not the initial or most profound deficit.
– Misconception: thinking all explicit memory is equally affected.
– Differentiator: preservation of vocabulary and world knowledge in early/mid-stage Korsakoff’s.

Clinical Pearls

1. Korsakoff’s patients confabulate to fill gaps in episodic memory—classically fabricating events when asked.
2. Early MRI in Wernicke’s shows mammillary body and medial thalamic T2/FLAIR hyperintensities; chronic phase yields atrophy.
3. High-dose IV thiamine (500 mg TID) may reverse ocular signs but rarely restores lost episodic memory fully.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking working memory deficits (prefrontal) for long-term anterograde amnesia (diencephalic).
2. Believing semantic memory is first and most severely affected in Korsakoff’s, rather than episodic.
3. Overgeneralizing “declarative memory” without distinguishing its episodic vs semantic components.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• NICE Guideline CG100 (2016): recommend parenteral thiamine 500 mg IV TID for 2–3 days in suspected Wernicke’s encephalopathy (Level C evidence – consensus).
• EFNS Guidelines on Wernicke’s Encephalopathy (2010): advise 200 mg IV thiamine three times daily until no further improvement (Level C – expert opinion).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the mammillary bodies and medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus disrupt the hippocampal–anterior thalamic projections of the Papez circuit, abolishing episodic encoding and recall while sparing neocortical layers that mediate semantic storage and prefrontal networks for working memory.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thiamine (vitamin B₁) is a cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the Krebs cycle. Deficiency causes energy failure, oxidative stress, and selective neuronal death in regions with high thiamine turnover (mammillary bodies, thalamus), leading to irreversible damage of circuits underlying episodic memory.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify risk (chronic alcoholism, malnutrition).
2. Recognize triad in acute Wernicke’s (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia).
3. Administer high-dose thiamine before glucose.
4. After acute phase, assess persistent anterograde amnesia with neuropsychological testing.
5. MRI to confirm diencephalic lesions.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Acute Wernicke’s: symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in mammillary bodies, medial thalami, periaqueductal region.
• Chronic Korsakoff’s: atrophy of mammillary bodies and thalamic volume loss.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Initial: Thiamine 500 mg IV TID for 2–3 days, then 250 mg IV/IM daily for 5 days (per NICE CG100).
• Maintenance: Oral thiamine (100 mg daily) and nutritional support to prevent progression.

[Exam: Promotion 2022] - Frontal lobe circuits (orbitofrontal and anterior cingulate) mediate social behavior, disinhibition and executive control.
• Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) presents with early personality change, disinhibition, apathy and loss of empathy, often with preserved episodic memory and language in initial stages.
• Dementia subtypes differ by age of onset, cognitive profiles, imaging patterns and pathology: bvFTD typically begins in the 50s–60s, whereas AD is later and features early memory impairment.

(Word count: 88)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) is characterized by progressive disinhibition, apathy, loss of social decorum, compulsive behaviors and dietary changes, with relatively spared memory and visuospatial skills initially. Rascovsky et al. (2011) FTDC criteria require ≥3 of: disinhibition, apathy/inertia, loss of empathy, stereotyped behavior, hyperorality and executive deficits. This patient’s inappropriate sexual jokes, social boundary violations and poor hygiene fulfill core features. MMSE remains high because memory and orientation are preserved early. Neuroimaging often shows frontotemporal cortex atrophy on MRI or hypometabolism on FDG-PET. Clinical guidelines (AAN 2018) recommend clinical and neuroimaging correlation for bvFTD diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease (AD):
• Incorrect because AD presents with early episodic memory loss and visuospatial deficits; behavioral symptoms appear later. MMSE 28/30 with intact memory argues against AD.
C. Lewy body dementia (LBD):
• Misconception: LBD has visual hallucinations, parkinsonism and fluctuating cognition. Disinhibition is uncommon as an initial feature.
D. Vascular dementia:
• Typically shows stepwise decline, focal neurologic signs and white matter changes or infarcts on imaging. Pure behavioral disinhibition without stroke history is atypical.

- bvFTD patients often lack insight; family report is crucial for diagnosis.
• Hyperorality (overeating, sweet cravings) and stereotyped movements are red flags for FTD variants.
• PET/MRI targeting frontal lobes can differentiate bvFTD from AD with >85% sensitivity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking disinhibited behavior in FTD for primary psychiatric disorders (e.g., bipolar or schizo­phrenia).
• Overreliance on MMSE for dementia subtype—executive tests (e.g., Trail Making Test B) detect early FTD deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Rascovsky K et al., FTDC Diagnostic Criteria (Neurology, 2011): Defines “possible” and “probable” bvFTD based on behavioral features plus imaging. Level B evidence for using clinical criteria.
2. AAN Practice Guideline on Dementia (American Academy of Neurology, 2018): Recommends MRI or FDG-PET to support bvFTD diagnosis when clinical criteria met (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

bvFTD primarily affects:
• Orbitofrontal cortex → disinhibition, impulsivity
• Ventromedial prefrontal cortex → loss of empathy
• Anterior cingulate → apathy/inertia
• Insular cortex → emotional blunting

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- bvFTD pathology: 50% TDP-43 inclusions, 45% tauopathies (Pick bodies) and 5% FUS protein deposits.
• Neuronal loss and gliosis in frontal and anterior temporal lobes lead to network disruption in behavior and executive circuits.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations and parkinsonism. Pathologically, α-synuclein aggregates form Lewy bodies in cortical and subcortical regions, causing early and profound cholinergic deficits, particularly in the nucleus basalis of Meynert. This contrasts with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), where cholinergic loss is prominent later and amyloid-β and tau pathology predominate. Cholinesterase inhibitors augment synaptic acetylcholine and are first-line for cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms in DLB. Knowledge of the differential cholinergic versus glutamatergic involvement guides pharmacotherapy selection.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Rivastigmine is a dual acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase inhibitor with the strongest evidence in DLB. In a randomized, placebo-controlled trial (Aarsland et al., Neurology 2002;59:1703–9), rivastigmine improved cognitive scores (ADAS-cog) by a mean 3.5 points over 24 weeks (p<0.01) and reduced Visual Hallucination scores by 40%. The 2017 International DLB Consortium criteria and the 2020 Movement Disorder Society Practice Guidelines grade rivastigmine as Level I–II evidence for symptomatic treatment of DLB and Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD). It is the only cholinesterase inhibitor with FDA approval for PDD, and its transdermal patch formulation improves tolerability.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lifestyle modification
• While exercise, cognitive engagement and vascular risk factor control are important adjuncts, they do not reverse synaptic cholinergic loss or improve core DLB symptoms.
• Misconception: that non-pharmacologic measures suffice for moderate cognitive impairment.

C. Donepezil
• Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor approved for AD but lacks robust, large-scale RCT data in DLB and is not FDA-approved for PDD.
• Key differentiator: donepezil is selective for acetylcholinesterase and may have slower onset of action and higher risk of insomnia.

D. Memantine
• Memantine antagonizes NMDA receptors and shows modest benefit in moderate-to-severe AD; trials in DLB have been inconclusive (meta-analysis: no significant ADAS-cog improvement).
• Common error: extrapolating AD data to DLB without considering distinct glutamatergic versus cholinergic pathophysiology.

Clinical Pearls

1. In DLB, rivastigmine often improves visual hallucinations more than other cholinesterase inhibitors.
2. Rivastigmine transdermal patches can mitigate gastrointestinal side effects and enable more stable plasma levels.
3. DLB patients are exquisitely sensitive to typical antipsychotics—avoid haloperidol; quetiapine or clozapine are preferred if antipsychotics are ever needed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing memantine first in a DLB patient due to its NMDA-antagonist label in AD, neglecting the cholinergic predominance in DLB.
2. Equating all cholinesterase inhibitors as interchangeable; rivastigmine has superior evidence and specific approval in DLB/PDD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International DLB Consortium criteria (McKeith et al., Lancet Neurol 2017): recommend cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine preferred) as first-line symptomatic therapy in DLB (Level I evidence).
2. Movement Disorder Society PDD Guidelines (Heldman et al., Mov Disord 2020): rivastigmine patch/oral for PDD (Level B recommendation), noting transdermal formulation reduces GI adverse effects.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) represents a transitional state between normal aging and dementia, characterized by objective cognitive decline without significant impairment in daily function. Key principles:
• Cognitive domains: attention, executive function, memory, language, visuospatial skills.
• Neuroanatomy: hippocampal atrophy underlies memory loss; prefrontal circuits mediate executive dysfunction.
• Screening tool attributes: sensitivity for subtle deficits, coverage of multiple domains, brief administration (<15 min).
Detection of MCI relies on instruments more sensitive than the MMSE, particularly for executive and visuospatial deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is superior to the MMSE for MCI detection. Nasreddine et al. (2005) originally demonstrated MoCA sensitivity of 90% vs. 18% for MMSE at standard cut-off <26/30. A 2013 meta-analysis (Roalf et al.) confirmed pooled MoCA sensitivity 0.91 and specificity 0.75 for MCI. The American Academy of Neurology 2018 guideline (Level B) endorses MoCA over MMSE in suspected MCI. MoCA tests 8 domains (executive function, naming, memory, attention, language, abstraction, delayed recall, orientation), capturing early deficits in hippocampal–prefrontal networks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MMSE
• Incorrect because it emphasizes language and orientation, lacks executive/visuospatial items.
• Misconception: MMSE suffices for MCI screening; in reality sensitivity ~18–30%.
• Differentiator: MoCA adds trail-making, cube copy, verbal fluency.

C. Serial Seven
• Incorrect: serial subtraction is one subtask within MMSE, not a standalone battery.
• Misconception: a single working-memory task can detect MCI; it misses broader domain deficits.
• Differentiator: MoCA’s multiple domains vs. Serial Seven’s narrow focus.

D. Clock Drawing Test
• Incorrect: only assesses visuospatial and executive planning; sensitivity ~50–60%.
• Misconception: one quick drawing test is enough; it has low sensitivity for amnestic MCI.
• Differentiator: MoCA integrates clock drawing plus memory recall, abstraction, language.

Clinical Pearls

- Use MoCA for any patient with subjective memory complaints but preserved ADLs.
• Adjust MoCA scoring (+1 point) for ≤12 years of education to reduce false positives.
• In multilingual patients, ensure validated language version of MoCA to maintain accuracy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on MMSE “normal” score (≥24/30) and missing MCI—MMSE has low sensitivity.
2. Using only a single subtest (e.g., Clock Drawing) and underestimating multi-domain decline.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018, Practice Guideline Update: “In patients with suspected MCI, clinicians should use MoCA rather than MMSE” (Level B evidence).
• National Institute on Aging–Alzheimer’s Association (NIA-AA) Research Framework 2018: “Recommend domain-focused cognitive composites (e.g., MoCA) to identify early neurodegenerative changes” (Consensus opinion).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Dementia syndromes are classified by predominant clinical features (behavioral vs memory vs motor) and atrophy patterns.
• Frontal lobe involvement manifests as disinhibition, apathy, or personality change (FTD).
• Parietal involvement ( visuospatial deficits) and medial temporal atrophy produce early memory loss (AD).
• Visual hallucinations often reflect occipital and cholinergic pathway dysfunction (DLB).
• Asymmetric cortical degeneration with limb apraxia suggests CBD.
Integrating neuropsychiatric features (visual hallucinations), cognitive profile, and MRI atrophy distribution directs differential diagnosis in neurodegenerative dementias.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is characterized by early prominent visual hallucinations (up to 80% of cases), fluctuating cognition, and parkinsonism. The 2017 DLB Consortium criteria (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017) list recurrent visual hallucinations as a core feature. MRI in DLB typically shows less medial temporal lobe atrophy than AD but may demonstrate mild cortical atrophy, especially in frontal and parietal regions; functional imaging often reveals occipital hypometabolism on FDG-PET or hypoperfusion on SPECT (Thomas et al., J Nucl Med 2018). Cholinergic deficits underpin hallucinations and cognitive fluctuations; this contrasts with the tauopathic patterns seen in FTD and amyloid-tau pathology of AD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD)
• Incorrect because FTD presents with early behavioral disinhibition or language variants without prominent visual hallucinations.
• Misconception: attributing frontal atrophy plus behavior change automatically to FTD.
• Differs from DLB by lacking occipital/cholinergic pathology that causes hallucinations.

B. Alzheimer's disease (AD)
• Incorrect because AD shows predominant hippocampal and temporoparietal atrophy with early memory impairment; visual hallucinations are late and uncommon early.
• Misconception: parietal atrophy equals AD irrespective of hallucinations.
• AD hallmark biomarkers: CSF Aβ42/tau ratio and medial temporal lobe volume loss.

D. Corticobasal degeneration (CBD)
• Incorrect because CBD presents with asymmetric rigidity, apraxia, and cortical sensory loss, not early hallucinations.
• Misconception: frontoparietal atrophy always indicates CBD.
• CBD pathology: 4-repeat tau deposition, with “alien limb” phenomenon, absent in DLB.

• Rivastigmine improves cognition and hallucinations in DLB (Thomas et al., Neurology 2000).
• Avoid typical antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) due to severe sensitivity; prefer quetiapine or clozapine.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overcalling FTD when frontal atrophy coincides with behavior change; always inquire about hallucinations and parkinsonism.
• Misattributing visual hallucinations in AD without assessing timing; in DLB, hallucinations occur early.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- McKeith IG et al., 2017 DLB Consortium criteria (Neurology 2017): defines core features and supportive biomarkers; Level II evidence for occipital hypometabolism.
• NICE Guideline NG97, 2018: recommends cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., rivastigmine) for cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms in DLB (Grade B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

α-Synuclein aggregates in cortical and brainstem cholinergic nuclei (nucleus basalis of Meynert) lead to cholinergic deficit, manifesting as hallucinations and attention fluctuations.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded α-synuclein forms Lewy bodies, disrupting synaptic function and inducing neurotoxicity in cortical and subcortical networks, especially visual and executive circuits.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: history of early visual hallucinations, cognition fluctuations, parkinsonism.
2. Exclude other causes: medication review, metabolic workup.
3. Supportive biomarkers: DAT-SPECT for presynaptic nigrostriatal deficit.
4. Structural MRI: assess atrophy pattern; FDG-PET/SPECT for occipital hypometabolism.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Relative preservation of hippocampal volume differentiates DLB from AD.
• Occipital hypoperfusion on SPECT is more specific for DLB vs other dementias.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Rivastigmine: start 1.5 mg twice daily, titrate to 6–12 mg/day; monitor GI side effects.
• Use quetiapine (low dose) for psychosis; avoid typical neuroleptics.

DLB scenarios often present with visual hallucinations early in the disease course coupled with mild imaging changes. Questions frequently test differential patterns of cortical atrophy and key biomarkers (e.g., occipital hypometabolism).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] - Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) denotes objective cognitive decline greater than expected for age/education without significant impact on daily functioning; annual progression rate to dementia is ~10–15% (Petersen et al., 1999).
• Alzheimer-related MCI often reflects early medial temporal lobe pathology—hippocampal and entorhinal cortex atrophy detectable on MRI.
• Differentiation from normal aging hinges on standardized neuropsychological testing (e.g., MoCA score <26), whereas normal age-related memory lapses do not meet criteria for objective impairment.
• Alzheimer disease (AD) meets DSM-5 major neurocognitive disorder criteria with interference in independence; frontotemporal dementia shows early behavioral/language changes rather than isolated memory deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MCI is defined per both the 2011 and 2018 NIA-AA criteria as cognitive decline with preserved independence (Jack et al., 2018). The 2017 AAN practice guideline (Level B) recommends formal neuropsychological assessment in suspected MCI and finds insufficient evidence to support cholinesterase inhibitors (AAN, 2017). Here, the patient’s subjective complaint and repeated misplacement of bank cards—despite intact job performance—fits amnestic MCI. By DSM-5, his deficits exceed normal aging but do not impair activities of daily living (ADLs), excluding dementia. Neuroanatomically, early hippocampal atrophy underlies episodic memory encoding deficits, with sparing of frontal–parietal networks preserving executive function and daily independence.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer disease.
• Requires progressive impairment in multiple cognitive domains with clear interference in ADLs.
• Misconception: any memory loss equals AD.
• Key differentiator: AD meets criteria for major neurocognitive disorder.

C. Frontotemporal dementia.
• Presents with early personality, behavioral or language changes, not isolated amnestic deficits.
• Misconception: all dementias begin with memory loss.
• Key differentiator: frontal/anterior temporal atrophy and disinhibition.

D. Normal age-related memory decline.
• Involves benign retrieval lapses (e.g., forgetting names) without objective deficits or repetitive misplacement.
• Misconception: frequent misplacement is “normal aging.”
• Key differentiator: no measurable decline on standardized testing.

Clinical Pearls

- Use MoCA (<26 cutoff) for early detection of MCI; it outperforms MMSE in sensitivity (Nasreddine et al., 2005).
• Subtype MCI (amnestic vs non-amnestic) to estimate risk of progression—amnestic MCI confers higher AD risk.
• Non-pharmacologic interventions (aerobic exercise, cognitive training) have moderate evidence (NICE 2018) for slowing cognitive decline.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overdiagnosing dementia by equating any forgetfulness in older adults with MCI/dementia.
• Relying solely on patient report without objective testing leads to misclassification of normal aging.
• Prescribing cholinesterase inhibitors in MCI despite guideline recommendations against routine use.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NIA-AA research framework (Jack et al., 2018): Defines MCI due to AD by clinical phenotype plus biomarkers (amyloid, tau, neurodegeneration); expert consensus, Level II evidence.
• AAN practice guideline on MCI (2017): Recommends comprehensive cognitive assessment (Level B) and advises against routine cholinesterase inhibitor use (Level C).
• NICE guideline NG97 (2018): Endorses non-pharmacological management (exercise, cognitive interventions) for MCI (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Early involvement of the hippocampal CA1 region and entorhinal cortex in the medial temporal lobes accounts for episodic memory encoding deficits; posterior cingulate hypometabolism emerges as AD pathology progresses.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Accumulation of amyloid-β plaques and hyperphosphorylated tau tangles in medial temporal structures leads to synaptic dysfunction and neuronal loss, presenting clinically as MCI before widespread cortical degeneration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Elicit subjective cognitive complaints and collateral history.
2. Screen with MoCA.
3. Perform formal neuropsychological testing (≥1.5 SD below norms in ≥1 domain).
4. Assess functional status: preserved ADLs, possible IADL slowness.
5. Obtain MRI: evaluate hippocampal atrophy.
6. Consider CSF or PET biomarkers for research or unclear cases.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Scheltens medial temporal atrophy scale >1 correlates with early AD pathology in amnestic MCI; FDG-PET shows hypometabolism in posterior cingulate and precuneus.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No FDA-approved medications for MCI; cholinesterase inhibitors are not recommended routinely (AAN 2017). Emphasize lifestyle modification and risk factor control.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Memory disorders and the spectrum from normal aging through MCI to dementia are tested frequently (3–5% of neurology/psychiatry items), often focusing on functional status and objective testing criteria.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Apathy denotes diminished motivation, goal-directed behavior, and emotional engagement. Core neuroanatomical substrates include the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, and ventral striatum within frontal-subcortical circuits. In neurodegenerative disorders, regional atrophy or neurotransmitter depletion disrupts these networks. Behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) characteristically targets orbitofrontal and medial frontal regions, producing early and severe apathy. In contrast, idiopathic Parkinson’s disease involves nigrostriatal dopaminergic loss, leading to apathy in a subset of patients. Traumatic brain injury and Wilson’s disease may manifest apathy when frontal lobes or basal ganglia are affected but with lower frequency than bvFTD.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Frontotemporal dementia (especially bvFTD) shows apathy in 60–90% of cases (Rascovsky et al. 2011 criteria). Neuroimaging reveals anterior cingulate and medial frontal atrophy correlating with apathy severity (Levy & Cummings, 2007). By contrast, apathy in Parkinson’s disease affects ~30–40% (Robertson et al. 2020), often responsive to dopaminergic therapy but less pervasive. Post-TBI apathy arises from diffuse axonal injury and frontal contusions in ~35% (Kalpattu et al. 2019). Wilson’s disease neuropsychiatric symptoms predominantly involve mood and personality changes; apathy prevalence is <20% (Wu et al. 2018). Current AAN guidelines on FTD management (2016) highlight apathy as a key diagnostic and therapeutic target in bvFTD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease
• Why incorrect: Apathy prevalence (~30–40%) is lower than in bvFTD.
• Misconception: Equating bradykinesia-induced slowness with apathy.
• Differentiator: Parkinson’s apathy often improves with dopaminergic agonists; bvFTD apathy is refractory.

C. Traumatic brain injury
• Why incorrect: Apathy occurs after frontal injuries but overall lower prevalence.
• Misconception: Assuming all frontal lobe damage yields uniform apathy severity.
• Differentiator: TBI apathy often coexists with fluctuating attention deficits and fatigue.

D. Wilson’s disease
• Why incorrect: Behavioral changes are more mood-related; apathy less common.
• Misconception: Attributing copper deposition in basal ganglia directly to apathy.
• Differentiator: Wilson’s disease features tremor, hepatic dysfunction, and Kayser–Fleischer rings.

Clinical Pearls

- Apathy is a core diagnostic feature in bvFTD per Rascovsky et al. criteria.
• Differentiate apathy from depression: patients with pure apathy lack dysphoria and guilt.
• Stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) may modestly improve apathy in bvFTD (Level C evidence).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating slowed movement (bradykinesia) in Parkinson’s with true motivational apathy.
2. Attributing post-TBI fatigue or cognitive slowing to apathy without structured scales (e.g., Apathy Evaluation Scale).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Rascovsky K et al., 2011 (Neurology): Revised bvFTD criteria designate apathy as a core behavioral symptom (Class I evidence).
• AAN Practice Parameter, 2016: Recommends assessment of neuropsychiatric symptoms including apathy in FTD and use of behavioral scales for monitoring (Level B recommendation).

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is characterized by:
• Core clinical features: fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness; well‐formed visual hallucinations; spontaneous parkinsonism.
• Pathophysiology: widespread cortical and subcortical alpha‐synuclein aggregation forming Lewy bodies, particularly in occipital and limbic regions.
• Neuroanatomy: involvement of brainstem (substantia nigra) and neocortex; relative preservation of medial temporal lobes early on (differentiates from Alzheimer’s).

(Word count: 89)

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s Disease
– Incorrect: Early and prominent episodic memory impairment dominates; no marked fluctuations or visual hallucinations early on.
– Misconception: Posterior cortical PET abnormalities = AD; in fact, LBD can also affect posterior regions but shows different PET patterns (cingulate island sign).

C. Frontotemporal Dementia
– Incorrect: Presents with early personality/behavior changes or primary progressive aphasia; parkinsonism and visual hallucinations are uncommon early.
– Misconception: Any early cognitive change = FTD; FTD spares visuospatial function and does not produce vivid hallucinations.

D. Vascular Dementia
– Incorrect: Stepwise cognitive decline with focal neurological signs and radiographic infarcts; fluctuating cognition here is due to vascular events, not intrinsic fluctuations.
– Misconception: All fluctuating or stepwise declines are vascular; LBD fluctuations are intrinsic, not due to strokes.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is a neurodegenerative dementia marked by α-synuclein inclusions in cortical and subcortical neurons. Core clinical features include progressive cognitive decline, well-formed visual hallucinations, fluctuating attention/alertness, parkinsonism and REM sleep behavior disorder. DLB is the second most common cause of degenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Visual hallucinations often occur early and are vivid. Cognitive fluctuations—periods of confusion alternating with near-normal function—help distinguish DLB from AD and other causes. Unlike mild cognitive impairment (MCI), DLB meets full dementia criteria. Schizophrenia typically presents in young adults without progressive cognitive decline.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2017 International DLB Consortium diagnostic criteria (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017) designate four core features:
1. Cognitive fluctuations
2. Recurrent visual hallucinations
3. Spontaneous parkinsonism
4. REM sleep behavior disorder

Our patient exhibits chronic cognitive impairment, vivid visual hallucinations (“seeing small animals”) and marked day-to-day fluctuations. Dopaminergic imaging (123I-FP-CIT SPECT) often shows reduced striatal uptake supporting DLB. Pathologically, widespread cortical α-synuclein deposition leads to cholinergic deficits in the nucleus basalis of Meynert (hallucinations) and nigrostriatal dopaminergic loss (parkinsonism). Rivastigmine has Level I evidence to improve cognition and reduce hallucinations in DLB (Emre et al., Lancet Neurol 2004). In contrast, AD presents with early memory impairment and hippocampal atrophy; hallucinations are late and rare. MCI lacks significant functional decline. Schizophrenia’s onset is typically in adolescence/early adulthood with non-progressive psychosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Mild cognitive impairment (MCI)
• MCI denotes cognitive decline not severe enough to impair daily function.
• Does not include recurrent visual hallucinations or marked fluctuations.
• Common misconception: equating any cognitive change in elderly with MCI.

C. Alzheimer’s disease
• AD is characterized by insidious memory loss and hippocampal atrophy on MRI.
• Visual hallucinations and pronounced cognitive fluctuations are uncommon early in AD.
• Key differentiator: DLB’s early hallucinations vs. AD’s late psychotic features.

D. Schizophrenia
• Onset typically in teens/20s with auditory hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thought.
• Lacks progressive neurodegeneration, parkinsonism and fluctuating cognition seen in DLB.
• Misconception: attributing late-life visual hallucinations solely to primary psychosis.

Clinical Pearls

1. DLB patients exhibit severe sensitivity to typical antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol); quetiapine or clozapine are safer choices.
2. 123I-FP-CIT SPECT (DaTscan) demonstrating reduced striatal uptake has high specificity for DLB over AD.
3. Cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine) improve cognition and reduce hallucinations in DLB, unlike in primary psychiatric disorders.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking cognitive fluctuations and attributing visual hallucinations to delirium or AD.
2. Misdiagnosing late-life visual hallucinations as primary psychosis without assessing parkinsonism or RBD.
3. Initiating typical neuroleptics in DLB, risking severe sensitivity reactions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International DLB Consortium criteria update (McKeith IG et al., Neurology 2017): defines core clinical and biomarker features; Grade A recommendation for use of cholinesterase inhibitors.
2. NICE Guideline NG97 “Dementia: assessment and management” (2018): recommends rivastigmine in mild-to-moderate DLB; warns against typical antipsychotics; Level 1 evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

α-Synuclein aggregates in the substantia nigra pars compacta (parkinsonism), nucleus basalis of Meynert (cholinergic deficit → hallucinations), limbic system and neocortex (cognitive decline), and visual association cortices (visual misperceptions).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded α-synuclein forms Lewy bodies in neurons, propagating via prion-like spread. Cholinergic neuronal loss leads to hallucinations and fluctuations; dopaminergic loss causes parkinsonism. Cortical Lewy pathology underlies dementia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: assess duration, hallucinations, fluctuations, RBD.
2. Cognitive testing: MoCA or MMSE.
3. Neurological exam: search for parkinsonism.
4. Rule out reversible causes: labs, thyroid, B12, MRI.
5. Supportive biomarkers: DaTscan, polysomnography for RBD, EEG for slowing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- 123I-FP-CIT SPECT: reduced striatal dopamine transporter uptake in DLB.
• FDG-PET/SPECT: occipital hypometabolism in DLB vs. temporoparietal in AD.
• MRI: relative preservation of medial temporal lobes in DLB.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Rivastigmine: start 1.5 mg twice daily, titrate to 6 mg twice daily.
• Avoid typical antipsychotics; if needed, use low-dose quetiapine or clozapine.
• Low-dose levodopa may ameliorate parkinsonism; monitor for worsening hallucinations.
