[Exam: Part I 2019] Behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) is characterized by focal degeneration of the orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and anterior temporal lobes. Core clinical features include disinhibition, apathy, and hyperorality—manifesting as altered dietary preferences (e.g., sweet intake). Pathologically, bvFTD is associated with tau (FTLD-tau) or TDP-43 (FTLD-TDP) protein inclusions. MRI demonstrates asymmetric frontal and/or anterior temporal atrophy, aiding differentiation from Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which primarily affects hippocampi and parietal lobes. Recognition of these distinct neuroanatomical and behavioral patterns is essential for accurate early diagnosis and management.
(Word count: 108)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Frontotemporal dementia is the correct diagnosis because hyperorality, specifically a craving for sweets, is a core behavioral disturbance in bvFTD. According to the International Behavioural Variant FTD Criteria Consortium (FTDC) (Rascovsky et al., Ann Neurol 2011;70:378–396), hyperorality is one of five core features required for a probable bvFTD diagnosis. Structural MRI typically reveals frontal and anterior temporal lobe atrophy—findings noted on the patient’s imaging. In contrast, AD presents with early episodic memory deficits and medial temporal atrophy (Jack et al., NIA-AA 2011), vascular dementia shows multi-infarct patterns on imaging, and prion diseases progress rapidly with myoclonus and periodic EEG discharges (Zerr et al., Lancet Neurol 2021). Thus, the combination of specific behavioral change and frontotemporal atrophy is pathognomonic for bvFTD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease
– Incorrect because AD’s hallmark is early episodic memory loss and visuospatial deficits.
– Misconception: attributing any cognitive decline to AD.
– Differentiated by medial temporal atrophy on MRI and positive CSF Aβ42/tau profile.

C. Vascular dementia
– Incorrect: features stepwise focal deficits (e.g., hemiparesis) and white-matter hyperintensities.
– Misconception: vascular risk factors always imply vascular dementia.
– Differentiated by patchy infarcts on MRI and cerebrovascular history.

D. Prion disease
– Incorrect: presents with rapid progression (weeks–months), myoclonus, periodic sharp-wave EEG.
– Misconception: any dementia with behavioral change is prion-related.
– Differentiated by 14-3-3 protein in CSF and characteristic EEG changes.

• Hyperorality (sweet cravings, putting objects in mouth) is a key bvFTD sign often tested on boards.
• Genetic mutations (C9orf72, GRN, MAPT) account for ~30% of bvFTD—consider family history.
• SSRIs (e.g., sertraline 50–100 mg/day) can ameliorate compulsive eating and disinhibition.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overattributing hyperorality to Alzheimer’s disease when it is rare in AD.
2. Ignoring behavioral changes in elderly patients as “normal aging” rather than bvFTD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Behavioural Variant FTD Criteria Consortium (FTDC), Rascovsky et al. Ann Neurol 2011;70:378–396. Level B evidence. Establishes hyperorality as a core diagnostic feature.
• EFNS Task Force on Diagnosis and Management of Sporadic FTD, European Journal of Neurology 2011;18(5):597–615. Level C evidence. Recommends MRI and consensus clinical criteria for early bvFTD diagnosis.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the orbitofrontal cortex disrupts inhibitory control, producing disinhibition and hyperorality. Anterior temporal lobe involvement impairs social cognition and semantic processing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

bvFTD arises from FTLD-tau or FTLD-TDP proteinopathies leading to neuronal loss and gliosis in frontal/temporal lobes, sparing hippocampi until late stages.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: assess for disinhibition, apathy, hyperorality.
2. Cognitive testing: executive function focus (e.g., Frontal Assessment Battery).
3. MRI: frontal/anterior temporal atrophy.
4. Exclude AD (CSF Aβ/tau) and vascular lesions (MRI).
5. Genetic testing if family history positive.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI in bvFTD shows predominant atrophy of the ventromedial and orbitofrontal cortices and anterior temporal lobes; FDG-PET reveals hypometabolism in these regions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease-modifying drugs exist. Symptomatic management includes SSRIs for behavioral symptoms and occupational therapy for safety.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Apathy—defined as diminished motivation not attributable to decreased consciousness, cognitive impairment, or emotional distress—arises from disruption of frontal–subcortical circuits.
1. Frontal Lobes: The anterior cingulate cortex and orbitofrontal cortex regulate initiation and motivation.
2. Subcortical Circuits: The mesolimbic dopamine pathway (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) and dorsolateral prefrontal circuits modulate goal-directed behavior.
3. Disease Distribution: Neurodegenerative disorders differ in predilection for these networks; behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) targets frontal regions early, leading to prominent apathy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Frontotemporal dementia exhibits apathy in over 70–80% of patients at presentation, making it the most common neuropsychiatric feature. Rascovsky et al. (Lancet Neurol 2011) list apathy/inertia as a core clinical feature for probable bvFTD. Neuroimaging correlates demonstrate early atrophy and hypometabolism in bilateral anterior cingulate and orbitofrontal cortices, directly impairing motivational circuits (Seeley et al., Neuron 2008). By contrast, Alzheimer’s disease presents initially with episodic memory impairment; apathy emerges later in moderate stages (Robert et al., Alzheimer’s Dement 2006). Parkinson’s disease and PSP may show apathy secondary to dopaminergic deficit but at lower frequencies (~30–50%) and often accompanied by depression or akinetic-rigid features (Levy & Dubois, Brain 2006).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)
– Why incorrect: PSP prevalence of apathy is ~40–50%, less than FTD.
– Misconception: Students may think vertical gaze palsy disorders present with cognitive flattening only.
– Differentiator: PSP hallmark is early postural instability and vertical gaze palsy, not predominant apathy.

B. Parkinson's disease
– Why incorrect: Apathy occurs in ~30–45% of PD, often coexisting with depression or cognitive decline.
– Misconception: Equating parkinsonian bradykinesia with apathy.
– Differentiator: PD patients first present with motor symptoms (rest tremor, rigidity), whereas FTD presents with behavior changes.

D. Alzheimer's disease (AD)
– Why incorrect: Apathy appears later, typically in moderate stages, and follows memory loss.
– Misconception: Attributing early motivational deficits to AD rather than FTD.
– Differentiator: AD hallmark is episodic memory impairment and temporoparietal atrophy; FTD shows frontal atrophy with early apathy.

2. Assuming apathy in any dementia equals AD; overlooking FTD when disinhibition and personality change are present.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

FTD selectively affects the anterior cingulate cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, and connected striatal circuits—areas critical for motivation and goal-directed behavior.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

bvFTD shows neuronal loss and gliosis from tau or TDP-43 aggregates in frontal lobes, disrupting dopaminergic and glutamatergic transmission in motivation circuits.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical interview: assess for apathy vs depression
2. Neuropsychological testing: frontal executive tasks
3. MRI: evaluate frontal lobe atrophy
4. Apply Rascovsky criteria for probable bvFTD

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: asymmetric frontoinsula and anterior cingulate atrophy
• FDG-PET: hypometabolism in frontal and anterior temporal lobes

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No FDA-approved agents for apathy in bvFTD; off-label SSRIs (e.g., sertraline) or stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) may improve motivational deficits.

[Exam: Part II 2022] The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), developed by Folstein et al. (1975), is a 30-point cognitive screening tool used worldwide to quantify cognitive impairment. It comprises domains: orientation, registration, attention/calculation, recall, language, and visuospatial skills. Orientation (5 points for time, 5 for place) accounts for one-third of the total score, reflecting widespread cortical integration in temporal-parietal association areas. Registration and recall probe medial temporal structures (hippocampus) and short-term memory circuits; attention/calculation engages dorsolateral prefrontal networks. Recognizing domain weighting is essential for accurate scoring, longitudinal monitoring in dementia, and differential diagnosis between Alzheimer’s disease and other neurocognitive disorders. (Word count: 115)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Orientation carries 10/30 points (33%), the highest of all MMSE domains. Registration and recall each carry 3 points (10% each), attention/calculation 5 points (17%). Folstein’s original publication and subsequent validation studies confirm orientation items’ superior diagnostic sensitivity in early Alzheimer’s disease (sensitivity ~78%, specificity ~82%; Larner 2020). The emphasis on temporal and spatial orientation capitalizes on widespread cortical networks vulnerable in early dementia. Current dementia guidelines (NICE CG42, 2018) recommend use of the full MMSE for staging, with orientation sub-scores guiding severity classification.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Registration
• Carries only 3 points.
• Tests immediate memory span, not global orientation.
• Common misconception: memory encoding is most heavily weighted—actually lower.

C. Attention and calculation
• Worth 5 points (serial sevens or WORLD backward).
• Reflects frontal lobe function but less weight than orientation.
• Misconception: complex tasks equate to higher point value.

D. Recall
• Worth 3 points (delayed recall of three words).
• Evaluates short-term retrieval; often impaired in Alzheimer’s, but weighted equally to registration.
• Mistaken belief that recall dominates scoring—orientation surpasses it.

Clinical Pearls

- Orientation items (date, location) often decline earliest in Alzheimer’s disease.
• Use “WORLD” backward for low-education patients as an alternative to serial sevens.
• Monitor changes in orientation subscore to track progression; a 2-point drop correlates with clinically significant decline.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mis‐adding orientation by counting only date or day instead of all five time components.
• Confusing registration and recall sub‐scores, leading to misinterpretation of memory impairment severity.
• Assuming language items carry more weight than orientation because of perceived complexity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NICE Clinical Guideline CG42 (2018): Recommends the MMSE as part of initial dementia assessment; orientation sub-score used to stage severity (Recommendation: strong; Evidence level: 1++).
• USPSTF Recommendation Statement (2020): Concludes insufficient evidence (Grade I) to support routine cognitive screening in asymptomatic older adults, noting limitations of MMSE sensitivity/specificity in community settings.
• Larner AJ Meta-analysis (J Alzheimers Dis. 2020): Demonstrated orientation domain of MMSE has highest diagnostic accuracy in early Alzheimer’s (sensitivity 78%, specificity 82%; Level of evidence: 2a).

[Exam: Part I 2023] - Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) refers to a group of neurodegenerative syndromes in which language impairment is the most prominent early feature, due to focal atrophy of the dominant perisylvian cortex.
• Three clinical variants (Gorno-Tempini et al., Neurology 2011):
• Nonfluent/agrammatic: effortful speech, agrammatism, impaired syntax, spared single-word comprehension
• Semantic: fluent but empty speech, impaired naming and single-word comprehension, preserved repetition
• Logopenic: word-finding pauses, impaired naming and sentence repetition, intact single-word comprehension and grammar
• Early episodic memory lapses on MMSE can occur in logopenic PPA due to underlying Alzheimer pathology, but core deficits remain language-focused.

(105 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Primary progressive aphasia is diagnosed when language dysfunction is the principal early deficit persisting for at least two years, with relative sparing of other cognitive domains. In this case, the patient exhibits:
1. Impaired naming (lexical retrieval)
2. Impaired repetition (phonological loop deficit)
3. Preserved single-word comprehension and grammar
This constellation corresponds to the logopenic variant of PPA (lvPPA), per the 2011 International Consensus Criteria (Gorno-Tempini et al., Neurology 2011). LvPPA is most often underpinned by Alzheimer’s pathology (Josephs et al., Brain 2008), explaining mild episodic memory deficits on MMSE. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) variants either impair comprehension (semantic) or motor speech (nonfluent) early, and typical Alzheimer’s disease presents with predominant episodic memory loss and visuospatial deficits before focal aphasia. Thus, the umbrella diagnosis of Primary Progressive Aphasia best encompasses the findings.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Semantic dementia
• Incorrect because semantic variant PPA demonstrates markedly impaired single-word comprehension and loss of conceptual knowledge, with preserved repetition. Here, comprehension is intact.

C. Frontotemporal lobe dementia
• Behavioral variant FTD presents with early personality and executive dysfunction; language deficits are not the predominant or isolated early feature.

D. Alzheimer’s disease
• Typical Alzheimer’s features early episodic memory and visuospatial impairments; focal language deficits (naming, repetition) are less isolated and occur later, not as the presenting symptom.

• Early speech therapy focusing on phonological loop exercises can slow language decline in lvPPA.
• Unlike svPPA, lvPPA patients retain conceptual knowledge—test with semantic association tasks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing impaired naming in svPPA with lvPPA: in svPPA, single-word comprehension is also lost.
2. Attributing all progressive aphasias to Alzheimer’s disease; only lvPPA is most commonly Alzheimer’s-related, whereas nonfluent and semantic variants align with FTD pathology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Gorno-Tempini et al., Neurology 2011 (International Consensus Criteria for PPA): Defines three PPA variants with diagnostic features (Level C, expert consensus).
2. Jack et al., Alzheimer’s & Dementia 2018 (NIA-AA Research Framework): Recommends biomarker characterization (A/T/N) in atypical Alzheimer’s presentations, including lvPPA, to confirm underlying pathology (Level B, moderate evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- LvPPA: Atrophy and hypometabolism in left posterior superior temporal gyrus and inferior parietal lobule (Gorno-Tempini et al., 2008).
• SvPPA: Anterior temporal pole involvement.
• Nonfluent PPA: Left inferior frontal gyrus and insula.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- LvPPA reflects focal neurodegeneration within the phonological loop circuit (temporoparietal junction), often due to Alzheimer’s tau and amyloid accumulation.
• Progressive neuronal loss leads to breakdown of phonological encoding and retrieval networks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: progressive language decline >2 years
2. Detailed speech/language battery (naming, repetition, comprehension)
3. MRI brain: focal atrophy pattern
4. FDG-PET or SPECT: region‐specific hypometabolism
5. CSF or PET amyloid/tau biomarkers to differentiate AD vs FTD pathology
6. Genetic testing if family history or early onset

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: Asymmetric left‐sided atrophy in posterior perisylvian cortex for lvPPA
• FDG-PET: Hypometabolism in left inferior parietal lobule and superior temporal gyrus

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No FDA-approved disease-modifying agents for PPA variants.
• In lvPPA with confirmed Alzheimer’s pathology, cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) may provide modest benefit (Level C).
• Non-pharmacologic: tailored speech and language therapy remains cornerstone.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is a neurodegenerative syndrome characterized by isolated, progressive language impairment for at least two years before other cognitive domains are affected. Three main variants are recognized by the 2011 Gorno-Tempini et al. consensus criteria:
• Nonfluent/agrammatic: effortful speech, agrammatism, speech apraxia
• Semantic: fluent but empty speech, impaired naming and single-word comprehension
• Logopenic: word‐finding pauses, impaired repetition, phonological errors, preserved single‐word comprehension

The logopenic variant localizes to left posterior perisylvian and inferior parietal regions. Differentiating these variants from other dementias (e.g., semantic dementia, Alzheimer’s) rests on a detailed language examination (naming, repetition, comprehension) and correlating focal atrophy patterns on imaging.

(Approx. 130 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

In this patient, impaired naming and repetition with intact comprehension are hallmarks of the logopenic variant of PPA. According to the International Consensus Criteria (Gorno-Tempini et al., Brain 2011; level II evidence), logopenic PPA presents with:
• Prominent anomia and word‐finding pauses
• Impaired sentence and phrase repetition
• Phonological errors on spontaneous speech and naming tasks
• Relative preservation of single‐word comprehension and motor speech

Mesulam et al. (Ann Neurol 2003) demonstrated that logopenic PPA correlates pathologically with Alzheimer-type tauopathy or β-amyloid deposition in the left temporoparietal cortex. Structural MRI typically shows asymmetric atrophy in the left posterior perisylvian and inferior parietal regions (Rohrer et al., Neurology 2010). Clinical practice guidelines from the American Academy of Neurology (2018 update) recommend classifying PPA by variant to inform prognosis and potential trial eligibility (level C recommendation). Thus, “Primary progressive aphasia” is the most precise diagnosis, encompassing the logopenic variant in this presentation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Semantic dementia
• Incorrect because semantic variant PPA has impaired naming and single‐word comprehension, with fluent but empty speech.
• Misconception: equating “naming difficulty” alone with semantic variant.
• Key differentiator: intact comprehension in this patient rules out semantic dementia.

C. Frontotemporal lobe dementia
• FTD (behavioral variant) features early personality changes, disinhibition, and executive dysfunction, not isolated language deficits.
• Misconception: any language impairment equals FTD.
• Differentiator: absence of prominent behavioral/executive symptoms early on.

D. Alzheimer’s disease
• Early Alzheimer’s shows episodic memory loss and visuospatial deficits; language is affected later and repetition is typically preserved until late stages.
• Misconception: any memory complaint in older adults is Alzheimer’s.
• Differentiator: early word‐finding and repetition deficits point to PPA, not typical Alzheimer’s.

Clinical Pearls

- The logopenic variant of PPA often reflects underlying Alzheimer pathology; CSF or PET β-amyloid can confirm.
• Early referral to speech‐language therapy can prolong functional communication in PPA.
• Naming plus repetition testing (e.g., “No ifs, ands, or buts”) is highly sensitive for distinguishing PPA variants.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all PPA = semantic variant; many students overlook preserved comprehension in logopenic.
2. Conflating behavioral FTD with language-predominant variants; absence of early behavioral change is key.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Gorno-Tempini ML et al., Brain 2011 (International Consensus Criteria, level II): Defines diagnostic criteria for PPA variants, emphasizing language domains.
2. Wicklund MR et al., Neurology 2020 (American Academy of Neurology, level C): Recommends variant classification for trial eligibility and prognostication; supports use of amyloid biomarkers in logopenic PPA.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Logopenic PPA correlates with focal atrophy and hypometabolism in the left posterior perisylvian region, including the inferior parietal lobule (angular gyrus) and posterior superior temporal gyrus—areas critical for phonological processing and verbal working memory.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Underlying pathology in logopenic PPA is most often Alzheimer’s disease with β-amyloid plaques and tau neurofibrillary tangles.
• Neurodegeneration disrupts the dorsal speech‐processing stream (arcuate fasciculus), impairing repetition and phonological assembly.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed language history and neuropsychological testing (Boston Naming Test, sentence repetition tasks)
2. Structural MRI to identify focal atrophy
3. FDG-PET or SPECT for hypometabolism in language networks
4. CSF or amyloid PET if Alzheimer pathology suspected
5. Exclude other causes (stroke, tumor) with appropriate labs and imaging

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: Asymmetric atrophy of left temporoparietal junction in logopenic PPA.
• FDG-PET: Hypometabolism in left inferior parietal and posterior temporal regions distinguishes from semantic (anterior temporal) and nonfluent (inferior frontal) variants.

[Exam: Part I 2023] • Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is a neurodegenerative synucleinopathy characterized by early visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and REM sleep behavior disorder.
• Key pathology: cortical and subcortical alpha-synuclein aggregates (Lewy bodies) leading to cholinergic and dopaminergic deficits.
• Differential diagnosis includes Alzheimer’s disease (predominant memory impairment, later visual symptoms), vascular dementia (stepwise decline, focal deficits), and psychiatric disorders (earlier onset, psychosis without progressive dementia).

Evidence-Based Analysis

DLB is identified by the 2017 revised consensus criteria (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017) requiring dementia plus two of the following core features:
1. Recurrent visual hallucinations of well-formed images
2. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness
3. REM sleep behavior disorder (dream enactment)
4. Parkinsonism (often bradykinesia, rigidity).
This patient exhibits visual hallucinations (“small animals”), fluctuations in cognition, and probable REM sleep behavior disorder, fulfilling core features. PET studies often show occipital hypometabolism, and MRI shows relative preservation of medial temporal lobes (O’Brien et al., Lancet Neurol 2014). Cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine) are first-line for cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms (Level A recommendation, AAN 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease
– Incorrect because early prominent memory loss and hippocampal atrophy on imaging are typical; visual hallucinations and marked fluctuations are late or absent.
– Misconception: any dementia with hallucinations equals AD. In AD, hallucinations usually occur at advanced stages.

C. Schizophrenia
– Incorrect due to age of onset (young adulthood) and absence of progressive cognitive decline over years.
– Misconception: visual hallucinations always psychiatric; in neurology, visual hallucinations often imply an organic cause.

D. Vascular dementia
– Incorrect because vascular dementia shows stepwise deficits, focal neurologic signs, and vascular lesions on MRI.
– Misconception: any fluctuating cognition is vascular; vascular fluctuations are stepwise, not waxing-waning day to day.

Clinical Pearls

• Early visual hallucinations in an elderly patient strongly suggest DLB rather than AD.
• Fluctuating cognition with “good” and “bad” days is a hallmark of DLB.
• Avoid typical antipsychotics in DLB due to severe neuroleptic sensitivity; use quetiapine or clozapine if needed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking Lewy body dementia for Alzheimer’s disease when memory deficits are mild early on.
• Overlooking REM sleep behavior disorder as a clue to synucleinopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2017 MDS DLB Criteria (McKeith et al., Neurology 2017): Updated core and supportive features with diagnostic specificity of ≥80%.
• AAN 2021 Dementia Guidelines: Recommend rivastigmine as first-line for DLB cognitive symptoms (Level A evidence, randomized controlled trials).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Cortical Lewy bodies in temporal, parietal, and occipital cortex disrupt cholinergic projections from the nucleus basalis of Meynert, leading to fluctuations and hallucinations.
• Brainstem involvement in the locus coeruleus and dorsal motor nucleus contributes to REM sleep behavior disorder.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Misfolded alpha-synuclein aggregates form Lewy bodies → synaptic dysfunction → neurotransmitter deficits (acetylcholine, dopamine) → clinical features of DLB.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: cognitive profile, hallucinations, fluctuations, sleep behavior
2. Neurologic exam: parkinsonian signs
3. Neuropsychological testing: visuospatial vs memory
4. MRI brain: rule out vascular lesions, assess medial temporal lobes
5. Functional imaging (SPECT/PET): occipital hypoperfusion
6. Polysomnography: confirm REM sleep behavior disorder

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Occipital hypometabolism on FDG-PET is more pronounced in DLB than AD.
• Relative preservation of hippocampal volume on MRI helps distinguish DLB from AD.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Rivastigmine: start 1.5 mg BID, titrate to 6–12 mg/day as tolerated.
• Caution with antipsychotics—use quetiapine or clozapine for psychosis, avoid haloperidol.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is characterized by objective cognitive decline (typically memory) without significant interference in daily activities.
Key concepts:
• Neurodegeneration in MCI is less severe than dementia; patients maintain independence.
• Distinction between MCI and Alzheimer’s dementia hinges on preserved functional status.
• Early intervention focuses on modifiable risk factors and nonpharmacologic strategies rather than antidementia drugs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lifestyle modification is first‐line for MCI. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline (Level B evidence) recommends structured physical exercise, cognitive training, and vascular risk factor control to slow progression. The FINGER trial (Ngandu et al., Lancet Neurol 2015) demonstrated that a multidomain intervention (diet, exercise, cognitive training, vascular risk management) improved or maintained cognitive function in at‐risk elderly. No cholinesterase inhibitor or memantine trial has shown consistent, clinically meaningful benefit in MCI; risks of nausea, syncope, bradycardia outweigh marginal gains. Therefore, nonpharmacologic approaches remain the standard.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Donepezil
• Why incorrect: AChE inhibitors have not demonstrated durable benefit in MCI; AAN guideline advises against routine use.
• Misconception: “Any memory complaint implies need for Alzheimer’s drugs.”
• Differentiator: Pharmacologic therapies reserved for diagnosed dementia, not MCI.

C. Memantine
• Why incorrect: NMDA‐receptor antagonist with efficacy only in moderate‐to‐severe Alzheimer’s dementia; no trials support its use in MCI.
• Misconception: “Neuroprotective agents are universally beneficial in early cognitive decline.”
• Differentiator: Indication limited to later‐stage disease when functional impairment is evident.

D. Rivastigmine
• Why incorrect: Like donepezil, limited to mild‐to‐moderate Alzheimer’s dementia; no approved role in MCI.
• Misconception: “All cholinesterase inhibitors are interchangeable across the dementia spectrum.”
• Differentiator: Side‐effect profile and lack of evidence preclude use in independent MCI.

Clinical Pearls

1. Multidomain interventions (physical activity + cognitive exercises) reduce conversion rates from MCI to dementia by up to 40% at 2 years (FINGER).
2. Controlling hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia is as important as formal “brain exercises” in preserving cognition.
3. Routine use of AChE inhibitors in MCI may expose patients to adverse events without delaying progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing donepezil or rivastigmine off‐label for MCI, expecting the same efficacy seen in Alzheimer’s dementia.
2. Equating subjective memory complaints with irreversible neurodegeneration—delaying evaluation of reversible causes (vitamin B12 deficiency, thyroid dysfunction).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (2018): Recommends exercise and cognitive training in MCI (Level B).
2. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE, 2021): Advocates lifestyle interventions; does not support routine pharmacotherapy for MCI.
3. FINGER Trial (Ngandu et al., 2015, Lancet Neurol): Multidomain lifestyle program improved global cognition (p<0.05) over 2 years.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative syndrome characterized by preferential degeneration of the frontal and anterior temporal lobes. Core concepts:
• Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) manifests with early personality changes—disinhibition, apathy, compulsive behaviors, and hyperorality (including craving sweets).
• Neuroanatomy: orbitofrontal cortex and anterior insula atrophy correlate with disinhibition and altered food preferences.
• Imaging: MRI shows focal frontal and/or temporal lobe atrophy; FDG-PET demonstrates hypometabolism in the same regions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is FTD because this patient’s predilection for sweets (“sweet tooth”) reflects hyperorality, a hallmark of bvFTD. The 2011 international consensus criteria (Rascovsky et al., Neurology 2011) require at least three of six behavioral features—early dietary changes among them—for probable bvFTD, plus supportive imaging findings. Alzheimer’s disease typically presents with episodic memory loss and hippocampal atrophy, not isolated behavioral changes. Vascular dementia shows stepwise cognitive decline with multiple infarcts, often with focal neurologic signs. Prion disease (e.g., Creutzfeldt–Jakob) is rapidly progressive, with myoclonus, periodic EEG complexes, and diffuse cortical ribboning on MRI. Frontotemporal lobar degeneration subtypes (tau vs. TDP-43 pathology) both present behaviorally, but imaging-driven diagnosis aligns with clinical criteria.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer's disease
• Incorrect: Predominant early amnestic deficits and medial temporal atrophy.
• Misconception: Attributing any dementia to Alzheimer’s.
• Differentiation: Lack of hyperorality and personality change; PET shows parietal-posterior cingulate hypometabolism.

C. Vascular dementia
• Incorrect: Characterized by stepwise decline, focal deficits, white matter changes or lacunes.
• Misconception: Assuming vascular disease causes all late-life behavior changes.
• Differentiation: MRI shows infarcts/white-matter hyperintensities, not isolated frontal atrophy.

D. Prion disease
• Incorrect: Rapid course (<1 year), myoclonus, cerebellar signs, periodic sharp-wave complexes on EEG.
• Misconception: Equating any frontally predominant atrophy with prionopathy.
• Differentiation: Diffuse cortical ribboning on DWI MRI and 14-3-3 CSF protein positivity.

• Early dietary changes—sweet cravings, overeating—are virtually pathognomonic of bvFTD.
• FDG-PET hypometabolism in orbitofrontal regions supports the diagnosis when MRI is equivocal.
• Management is supportive: SSRIs can reduce compulsive behaviors; trazodone may improve disinhibition.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overdiagnosing Alzheimer’s disease in younger patients with behavioral changes—bvFTD predominates under age 65.
2. Attributing hyperorality to depression or delirium—evaluate for frontal lobe syndromes and obtain neuroimaging.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) is a clinical syndrome of isolated, progressive language impairment. The non‐fluent/agrammatic variant (nfvPPA) is defined by effortful, halting speech with grammatical errors and apraxia of speech. Neuroanatomically, it localizes to the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus (Broca’s area) and opercular/insular cortex. nfvPPA falls within the frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) spectrum, most commonly FTLD‐tau. Recognizing the specific aphasia subtype with corresponding imaging atrophy patterns is essential for accurate diagnosis and prognostication.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The International Consensus Criteria (Gorno-Tempini et al., 2011) define nfvPPA by (1) agrammatism in language production and/or (2) apraxia of speech, with preserved single-word comprehension and object knowledge. MRI/FDG‐PET shows focal atrophy/hypometabolism in the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus and insula. Neuropathology studies (Josephs et al., 2010) report FTLD‐tau in ~60–70% of nfvPPA. Alzheimer’s disease more often underlies the logopenic variant (lvPPA) with word‐finding pauses, impaired repetition, and temporoparietal atrophy with amyloid‐beta and tau deposition on PET. Vascular dementia presents stepwise deficits with subcortical infarcts on MRI; prion disease features rapid decline, myoclonus, periodic EEG discharges, and 14-3-3 protein in CSF. The combination of agrammatic speech and fronto-insular degeneration is diagnostic of FTD (nfvPPA).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease
• Alzheimer’s produces lvPPA with word-finding pauses and impaired sentence repetition, not agrammatism.
• Imaging shows temporoparietal atrophy/hypometabolism and positive amyloid PET.

C. Vascular dementia
• Language deficits are heterogeneous and accompanied by stepwise cognitive decline and infarcts on MRI.
• No focal Broca‐area degeneration; speech errors are secondary to white matter disruption.

D. Prion disease
• Rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus, ataxia, periodic sharp‐wave EEG, and positive CSF 14-3-3.
• Agrammatic aphasia is rare; imaging shows cortical ribboning on DWI.

• FDG-PET increases early diagnostic accuracy by highlighting left fronto-insular hypometabolism.
• Emerging tau‐PET tracers (e.g., ^18F-flortaucipir) may distinguish FTLD-tau from AD pathology in vivo.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing lvPPA’s word‐finding pauses and impaired repetition with true agrammatism of nfvPPA.
2. Attributing progressive non‐fluent speech to ischemic Broca’s stroke rather than degenerative PPA.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International consensus criteria for PPA (Gorno-Tempini et al., 2011; Neurology): Use specific clinical features and imaging to classify PPA subtypes. Level B evidence.
• AAN Practice Guideline Update: Evaluation and Management of Dementia (2018; American Academy of Neurology): Recommend MRI/FDG-PET and CSF/PET biomarkers in suspected PPA to differentiate AD from FTLD. Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration in the left posterior inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann areas 44/45), operculum, and insular cortex disrupts the dorsal language stream, producing agrammatism and apraxia of speech.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

FTLD-tau pathology leads to neuronal and glial tau inclusions, preferentially targeting frontal and insular networks. Selective network vulnerability underlies the focal presentation of nfvPPA.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: insidious language decline >2 years.
2. Neuropsychological testing: assess fluency, grammar, comprehension.
3. Structural MRI: evaluate focal atrophy.
4. FDG-PET: confirm regional hypometabolism.
5. CSF/PET biomarkers: exclude Alzheimer’s pathology.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: asymmetrical atrophy of left inferior frontal and insular cortex.
• FDG-PET: focal hypometabolism in the same region.
• Negative amyloid PET favors FTLD over AD.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] - Alpha-synuclein aggregation in Lewy bodies affects cortical and subcortical networks, especially the limbic system and neocortex, producing early visual hallucinations and cognitive fluctuations.
• Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert contributes to attentional deficits and visuoperceptual disturbances.
• REM sleep behavior disorder reflects dysfunction of ponto‐medullary inhibitory circuits, a prodromal marker for synucleinopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2017 revised DLB Consortium criteria designate four core clinical features: (1) fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness; (2) recurrent visual hallucinations; (3) REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD); and (4) parkinsonism of mild severity. This patient exhibits visual hallucinations (“small animals”), documented RBD (acting out dreams), and marked day-to-day cognitive fluctuations—meeting criteria for probable Lewy body dementia.
Imaging biomarkers (e.g., reduced occipital uptake on FDG-PET, reduced striatal DAT uptake on SPECT) further support the diagnosis. Cholinesterase inhibitor therapy (rivastigmine) has Level B evidence for cognitive and neuropsychiatric benefit in DLB (AAN 2021 guidelines). Neuroleptic sensitivity is a hallmark: typical antipsychotics may precipitate severe parkinsonism or neuroleptic malignant–like reactions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease
• AD presents with insidious episodic memory loss and progressive decline, without prominent cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, or RBD early in the disease.
• Pathology: extracellular amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (tau), not cortical Lewy bodies.

C. Schizophrenia
• Onset in late adolescence/early adulthood; primary psychotic disorder rarely begins at age ≥60.
• Psychotic symptoms in the elderly should prompt evaluation for neurodegenerative or metabolic causes, not primary schizophrenia.

D. Frontotemporal dementia
• FTD often features early behavioral disinhibition or language dysfunction, but visual hallucinations and RBD are uncommon.
• Imaging shows frontal and/or anterior temporal atrophy rather than posterior cortical and subcortical involvement typical of DLB.

2. Misattributing visual hallucinations in the elderly to primary psychiatric illness rather than neurodegenerative etiology.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Alzheimer’s disease features neuronal loss and synaptic dysfunction from β-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, especially in hippocampal and cortical regions. Core domains:
1. Cognitive decline (e.g., episodic memory loss) due to early involvement of hippocampus and entorhinal cortex.
2. Neuropsychiatric symptoms arising from degeneration of frontal-subcortical circuits (anterior cingulate, orbitofrontal cortex).
3. Executive and motivational network disruption leading to apathy—a loss of goal-directed behavior distinct from pure memory impairment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Apathy affects 50–70% of Alzheimer’s patients, making it the single most prevalent neuropsychiatric symptom (Robert et al. JNNP 2009; Lyketsos et al. JAMA 2002). It stems from atrophy and hypometabolism in the anterior cingulate and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, producing diminished initiative, interest and emotional responsiveness.
By contrast, while memory loss is universal, it reflects a cognitive domain rather than a neuropsychiatric “symptom.” Delusions (prevalence 20–40%) and disorientation (emerging later in disease) are less frequent primary presentations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Delusion
• Prevalence: ~20–40%, often in moderate to severe stages.
• Misconception: Confusing psychotic features with motivational deficits.
• Differentiator: Delusions involve false beliefs; apathy is lack of motivation.

C. Memory loss
• Prevalence: ~100% cognitive sign.
• Misconception: Equating the hallmark cognitive deficit with a behavioral symptom.
• Differentiator: Memory loss is a cognitive impairment, not a neuropsychiatric syndrome.

D. Disorientation
• Prevalence: ~30–50%, typically in mid to late stages.
• Misconception: Assuming early spatial disorientation equals most common symptom.
• Differentiator: Disorientation is episodic confusion, later in disease progression.

2. Use the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) to quantify apathy severity and monitor response to interventions.

1. Mistaking apathy for major depressive disorder: depression features guilt, hopelessness and dysphoria, which are absent in pure apathy.
2. Assuming the “most common symptom” refers to cognitive deficits—examiners often differentiate cognitive from neuropsychiatric domains.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) can co-occur in a clinical and pathological spectrum due to overlapping molecular mechanisms. Key concepts:
1. TDP-43 is an RNA-binding protein normally located in the nucleus; its mislocalization and aggregation drive neuronal toxicity.
2. Proteinopathies underlie neurodegenerative diseases—FTD subtypes include FTLD-TDP and FTLD-Tau based on the predominant aggregate.
3. In ALS-FTD, upper and lower motor neuron degeneration (corticospinal tracts, anterior horn cells) coincides with frontotemporal cortical atrophy.
Understanding the specific protein inclusion is essential for neuropathologic classification and informs emerging targeted therapies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

TDP-43 pathology is the hallmark of both sporadic ALS and approximately half of FTD cases. Neumann et al. (2006) first identified that >95% of ALS patients harbor hyperphosphorylated, ubiquitinated TDP-43 inclusions with nuclear clearance. Subsequent studies (Mackenzie et al., 2010) confirmed FTLD-TDP as the largest pathological FTD subgroup, accounting for ~50% of cases. Current International ALS Pathology Consortium guidelines (IAPC 2018) recommend TDP-43 immunohistochemistry for definitive postmortem diagnosis of ALS-FTD (Level B evidence). In contrast, tau aggregates predominate in Pick’s disease, ubiquitin is a non-specific inclusion marker, and SOD1 mutations represent a rare familial ALS subtype lacking TDP-43 pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Tau protein
• Incorrect because tauopathy underlies FTLD-Tau variants (Pick’s, PSP) but is absent in most ALS-FTD.
• Misconception: equating all FTD with tau aggregates.
• Differentiator: tau forms neurofibrillary tangles, not cytoplasmic TDP-43 inclusions.

C. Ubiquitin
• Ubiquitin tags proteins for degradation and is present in many inclusion bodies.
• Misconception: thinking ubiquitination itself defines disease subtype.
• Differentiator: ubiquitin co-localizes with TDP-43 but is not the primary pathogenic protein.

D. SOD1
• SOD1 mutations cause ~2% of familial ALS and show SOD1-positive inclusions without TDP-43 pathology.
• Misconception: generalizing SOD1 inclusion to all ALS.
• Differentiator: SOD1-ALS lacks TDP-43 mislocalization and is genetically distinct.

Clinical Pearls

- Immunohistochemical staining for TDP-43 is the gold standard for postmortem confirmation of ALS-FTD pathology.
• Genetic testing for C9orf72 hexanucleotide expansions is recommended in patients with combined ALS-FTD, as it correlates with TDP-43 pathology.
• ALS-FTD patients with TDP-43 pathology may respond differently in emerging antisense oligonucleotide trials targeting RNA metabolism.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all FTD with tau pathology: TDP-43 is actually more prevalent in FTD than tau in Western populations.
2. Overinterpreting ubiquitin positivity: ubiquitin simply marks aggregated proteins and does not indicate the primary pathogenic species.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International ALS Pathology Consortium (IAPC) guidelines, 2018: recommend routine TDP-43 immunohistochemistry for neuropathological confirmation of ALS and ALS-FTD (Level B evidence).
• Rascovsky et al., Lancet Neurol, 2011: consensus criteria for behavioral variant FTD include neuropathological subtyping into FTLD-TDP versus FTLD-Tau to guide diagnosis and research (Level B evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

TDP-43 normally regulates RNA splicing and transport. In ALS-FTD, TDP-43 undergoes hyperphosphorylation, ubiquitination, and cleavage, leading to cytoplasmic aggregation and nuclear depletion. This disrupts RNA homeostasis, impairs axonal transport, and triggers neuroinflammation, culminating in motor neuron death and frontotemporal cortical degeneration.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative syndrome marked by selective degeneration of the frontal and anterior temporal lobes. Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) commonly presents with early personality changes—apathy, disinhibition—and hyperorality or altered dietary habits. Neuroanatomically, orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate involvement underlies disinhibition and apathy, while anterior temporal degeneration contributes to semantic changes. Pathologically, FTD is associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) characterized by tau or TDP-43 protein aggregates. By contrast, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) typically begins with hippocampal involvement and episodic memory loss, vascular dementia shows stepwise deficits tied to cerebrovascular lesions, and Lewy body dementia features α-synuclein pathology with visual hallucinations and occipital hypometabolism.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Behavioral variant FTD is defined by the 2011 Rascovsky criteria: at least three of six core behavioral features (early disinhibition, apathy/inertia, loss of empathy, perseverative behaviors, hyperorality, executive deficits) plus imaging evidence of frontal/anterior temporal atrophy or hypometabolism. This patient demonstrates apathy, hyperorality and left frontal atrophy on MRI with corresponding FDG-PET hypometabolism—findings with ~92% sensitivity and ~81% specificity for bvFTD (Diehl-Schmid et al., Neurology 2007). In AD, FDG-PET classically shows parietal and posterior cingulate hypometabolism (Berti et al., Neurology 2011). Vascular dementia imaging reveals multifocal infarcts or white-matter changes, while Lewy body dementia shows occipital hypometabolism and has core clinical features of visual hallucinations and parkinsonism. European Federation of Neurological Societies guidelines (2011) endorse combined structural and functional imaging to distinguish FTD from other dementias.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Alzheimer’s disease
– Incorrect because AD presents with early episodic memory impairment and MRI/FDG-PET shows hippocampal and temporoparietal changes rather than frontal predominance. Misconception: equating apathy in AD with bvFTD.

C. Vascular dementia
– Incorrect as it exhibits a stepwise course tied to infarcts or small-vessel disease on MRI, not focal frontal-temporal atrophy and PET hypometabolism. Misconception: attributing apathy to subcortical vascular lesions.

D. Lewy body dementia
– Incorrect: LBD features early visual hallucinations, fluctuations, parkinsonism and occipital hypometabolism, not hyperorality or predominant frontal degeneration. Misconception: confusing behavioral changes with LBD’s psychiatric symptoms.

Clinical Pearls

• Hyperorality (overeating, carbohydrate craving) is highly specific to bvFTD.
• SSRIs (e.g., sertraline) can ameliorate behavioral disinhibition and compulsivity in FTD.
• Early-onset dementia with prominent behavioral change warrants genetic counseling (e.g., C9orf72, MAPT mutations).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Misdiagnosing bvFTD as major depressive disorder due to apathy and social withdrawal.
• Overlooking frontotemporal hypometabolism on PET as “nonspecific” aging change rather than diagnostic for FTD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Rascovsky et al. (International Behavioral Variant FTD Criteria Consortium), Neurology 2011: Probable bvFTD requires ≥3 core criteria + supportive imaging (Level III evidence).
• NICE Guideline NG97 “Dementia: assessment, management and support” (2018): Recommend structural imaging for all early-onset dementia to differentiate FTD; moderate-quality evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of orbitofrontal cortex and anterior cingulate underlies disinhibition and apathy; anterior temporal lobe involvement contributes to semantic and emotional processing deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Frontotemporal lobar degeneration results from misfolded tau (FTLD-tau) or TDP-43 (FTLD-TDP) protein aggregates, leading to neuronal loss and gliosis in frontotemporal networks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: evaluate behavioral, cognitive, motor signs
2. Neuropsychometric testing: executive and social cognition
3. MRI brain: assess frontal/anterior temporal atrophy
4. FDG-PET/SPECT: confirm region-specific hypometabolism
5. Laboratory workup: exclude reversible causes
6. Genetic testing if familial pattern

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI “knife-edge” atrophy of frontal poles and insula is characteristic. FDG-PET shows symmetric or asymmetric frontal/anterior temporal hypometabolism, distinguishing bvFTD from other dementias.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No FDA-approved disease-modifying agents. Symptomatic management includes SSRIs for behavioral symptoms, trazodone for sleep disturbances, and cautious antipsychotics for severe agitation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Dementia subtypes differ in etiology, pathology, and prevalence.
• Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most frequent cause (≈60–75% of cases).
• Vascular dementia results from cerebrovascular disease—large strokes or small‐vessel ischemia—leading to cognitive decline.
• Other dementias (Lewy body, frontotemporal) are less common.
• Recognizing epidemiology aids diagnosis and management; vascular risk‐factor control can slow progression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vascular dementia (VaD) accounts for approximately 15–20% of dementias in Western populations, making it the second most common subtype after AD. This ranking is supported by large epidemiological studies (e.g., 2020 Alzheimer’s Disease International report). The NINDS‐AIREN criteria (1993) remain a standard for VaD diagnosis, emphasizing temporal correlation between cerebrovascular events and cognitive decline. The SPRINT‐MIND trial (2019) demonstrated that intensive blood pressure control reduces incidence of mild cognitive impairment and VaD (HR 0.71; 95% CI, 0.57–0.89; level A evidence). Guideline recommendations (AHA/ASA 2011) endorse aggressive management of hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia to prevent or slow VaD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Dementia with Lewy bodies
• Incorrect: Prevalence ~5–15%, ranking third or fourth.
• Misconception: Visual hallucinations and parkinsonism → not epidemiologically second.
• Differentiator: Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, REM sleep behavior disorder.

C. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD)
• Incorrect: Prevalence ~5–10%, typically younger onset.
• Misconception: Behavioral changes = common subtype.
• Differentiator: Early personality changes, language dysfunction, focal frontal/temporal atrophy.

D. Alzheimer's disease
• Incorrect: AD is the most common cause (~60–75%), not second.
• Misconception: Equating “common dementia” without ranking; AD > VaD.
• Differentiator: Prominent memory impairment, hippocampal atrophy, β-amyloid/tau pathology.

- Control vascular risk factors (BP, lipids, glucose) to prevent or delay VaD (AHA/ASA guidelines).
• Stepwise cognitive decline and focal neurological signs (e.g., hemiparesis) strongly suggest VaD.
• MRI is superior to CT for detecting white matter hyperintensities and lacunes in VaD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming Alzheimer’s disease is always the second most common—VaD outranks other subtypes except AD.
2. Overlooking mixed dementia: up to 50% of elderly demented patients have both AD and vascular pathology, complicating epidemiology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 Vascular Cognitive Impairment Guidelines:
• Recommendation: Rigorous control of hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia to prevent cognitive decline (Class I, Level A).
2. SPRINT‐MIND Trial (The New England Journal of Medicine, 2019):
• Finding: Intensive SBP target (<120 mm Hg) reduced MCI and VaD incidence by 19% (HR 0.81; 95% CI, 0.67–0.99).
• Level of evidence: A.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Strategic infarcts in the thalamus, basal ganglia, and frontal white matter disrupt executive circuits causing cognitive impairment.
• Small vessel disease leads to diffuse white matter changes (leukoaraiosis) impacting processing speed.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Large‐vessel strokes produce focal deficits and stepwise decline.
• Chronic small‐vessel ischemia results in cumulative microinfarcts and demyelination, impairing cortical–subcortical networks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: Look for history of stroke or transient ischemic attack.
2. Neurocognitive testing: Emphasize executive function, processing speed.
3. Neuroimaging: MRI with FLAIR to identify lacunes and white‐matter hyperintensities.
4. Exclude reversible causes (e.g., B12 deficiency, thyroid dysfunction).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI FLAIR: Confluent periventricular white matter hyperintensities (Fazekas scale ≥2).
• CT: Multiple cortical infarcts, ventricular enlargement out of proportion to sulcal atrophy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No FDA‐approved medications specifically for VaD; cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) have modest benefits in mixed dementia (Level B evidence).
• Focus remains on antiplatelet therapy and vascular risk reduction.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Early-onset Alzheimer’s disease (EOAD) is often familial and autosomal dominant.
1. APP (amyloid precursor protein) is cleaved by β- and γ-secretases to generate Aβ peptides.
2. Presenilin‐1 (PSEN1) and presenilin‐2 (PSEN2) form the catalytic core of γ-secretase; mutations alter amyloid β42/40 ratio.
3. APOE ε4 modulates late-onset risk via Aβ clearance but is not deterministic for EOAD.
Understanding the differential genetic contributions informs prognosis, counseling, and research enrollment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSEN1 mutations account for ~65–80% of autosomal dominant EOAD and have the earliest mean age of onset (~42–45 years) compared with APP (~50 years) and PSEN2 (~55 years). PSEN1 variants increase Aβ42 production and aggregation more profoundly, driving rapid neurodegeneration in the hippocampus and association cortices. Rovelet-Lecrux et al. (2006) demonstrated that PSEN1 mutations consistently shift γ-secretase cleavage to longer, more aggregation-prone Aβ species. Current consensus (2018 NIA-AA Research Framework) recognizes PSEN1 pathogenic variants as definitive biomarkers for EOAD diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. APP
• Incorrect because APP mutations typically present later (mean ~50 years) and account for ~10–15% of familial EOAD.
• Misconception: equating any EOAD gene with the earliest onset.
• Differentiator: APP mutations alter β-secretase cleavage sites, not the core γ-secretase function.

B. APOE
• ε4 allele increases risk for late-onset AD and influences Aβ clearance, but is neither causative nor associated with earlier age at onset.
• Misconception: conflating risk modulation (APOE) with deterministic mutations.
• Differentiator: APOE status is a susceptibility factor, not a monogenic driver.

D. PSEN2
• Rare (<5% of familial EOAD) with later and more variable onset (~55 years), reduced penetrance.
• Misconception: presenilin mutations are equivalent in effect.
• Differentiator: PSEN2 mutations have subtler effects on γ-secretase activity and Aβ42 production.

Clinical Pearls

- PSEN1 mutations are the most common cause of familial EOAD and should prompt genetic counseling and cascade testing.
• APOE genotyping is not recommended for diagnostic confirmation of EOAD.
• Early identification of PSEN1 carriers (e.g., via DIAN) enables entry into presymptomatic trials targeting Aβ aggregation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating APOE ε4 carriage with monogenic causes—ε4 is a risk allele, not causative.
2. Assuming APP mutations universally present earlier than presenilin variants—PSEN1 has the earliest onset.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NIA-AA Research Framework (2018): Recommends autosomal dominant gene testing (APP, PSEN1, PSEN2) for definitive diagnosis in EOAD (Consensus level B).
• Bateman et al., DIAN study (NEJM 2012): Demonstrated that PSEN1 mutation carriers show biomarker changes (CSF Aβ42 decline, amyloid PET positivity) up to 25 years before symptom onset (Level 2 evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSEN1 encodes the catalytic subunit of γ-secretase. Mutations enhance cleavage at Aβ42-generating sites, elevating the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio. Excess Aβ42 oligomerizes, deposits as amyloid plaques, triggers tau phosphorylation, synaptic loss, and neuronal death predominantly in the medial temporal lobes and association cortices.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) denotes a group of neurodegenerative syndromes with insidious, predominant language impairment for >2 years before other domains are affected. The semantic variant (PPA-S) features a selective degeneration of conceptual knowledge, leading to fluent but “empty” speech, profound anomia, and single‐word comprehension deficits. Neuroanatomically, PPA-S correlates with asymmetric atrophy of the left anterior temporal lobe—particularly the temporal pole and inferior/middle temporal gyri—and is most often driven by TDP-43 type C pathology.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer B captures the hallmark of PPA-S: severe impairments in object naming (anomia) and single‐word comprehension despite preserved syntax and fluency (Hodges et al., Brain 1992). The 2011 International Consensus Criteria (Gorno-Tempini et al., Brain 2011) formalized these core features, specifying that PPA-S must demonstrate:
• Fluent, grammatically intact speech
• Impaired confrontation naming and single‐word comprehension
• Left anterior temporal atrophy on MRI and hypometabolism on FDG-PET
Postmortem studies show TDP-43 type C inclusions in 70–80% of cases (Irwin et al., Acta Neuropathol 2016). By contrast, other PPA variants display distinct language profiles and atrophy patterns (e.g., agrammatism with left inferior frontal atrophy in the nonfluent variant).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It affects fluency and grammar
• Incorrect: Describes the nonfluent/agrammatic variant (PPA-G), characterized by agrammatic speech and apraxia of speech due to left inferior frontal and insular atrophy. PPA-S preserves grammatical structure and speech fluency.

C. It is due to right temporal atrophy
• Incorrect: PPA-S atrophy is left-dominant. Right anterior temporal atrophy produces deficits in social‐emotional semantics and prosopagnosia (right temporal variant FTD), not the naming/comprehension deficits of PPA-S.

D. It is characterized by severe dysarthria
• Incorrect: Dysarthria reflects a motor‐execution disorder (e.g., in primary lateral sclerosis or motor variant PPA) and is not a core feature of PPA-S, where phonation and articulation remain intact.

Clinical Pearls

- Use the “Pyramids and Palm Trees” test to quantify semantic association deficits in PPA-S.
• Surface dyslexia (regularization errors on irregular words) often accompanies PPA-S due to degraded lexical‐semantic networks.
• Word-frequency effects: lower‐frequency, high-specificity nouns are lost earlier in PPA-S.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking fluent—but semantically empty—speech for intact language, leading to misdiagnosis as logopenic or even psychogenic aphasia.
2. Overlooking single-word comprehension testing and focusing solely on fluency, thereby missing the semantic impairment.
3. Conflating left versus right temporal atrophy, which yield language versus behavioral/social-emotional syndromes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Gorno-Tempini et al. International Consensus Criteria for PPA (Brain, 2011)
• Recommendation: Subclassify PPA into semantic, agrammatic/nonfluent, and logopenic variants based on core clinical and imaging features.
• Level of Evidence: IV (expert consensus).

2. National Institute on Aging–Alzheimer’s Association (NIA-AA) Research Framework (Alzheimers Dement, 2018)
• Recommendation: Apply biomarker-guided etiological classification; recognize that PPA-S is typically non-Alzheimer’s (amyloid-negative), whereas logopenic PPA often reflects underlying Alzheimer’s pathology.
• Level of Evidence: II (observational cohort studies).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The left anterior temporal lobe serves as a “semantic hub,” integrating information across modalities. Atrophy here disrupts stored conceptual knowledge, leading to naming and comprehension deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded TDP-43 type C aggregates accumulate in neurons and glia within the anterior temporal cortex, causing synaptic loss, neuronal death, and progressive semantic network disintegration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: insidious naming/comprehension decline >2 years
2. Neuropsychological testing: confirm fluent speech, poor naming, impaired single-word comprehension, preserved repetition
3. MRI/FDG-PET: identify left anterior temporal atrophy/hypometabolism
4. Exclude alternative etiologies: CSF/amyloid PET to rule out Alzheimer’s in atypical cases
5. Apply consensus criteria for PPA variant classification

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: focal, asymmetric atrophy of the left temporal pole and anterior inferior/middle temporal gyri.
• FDG-PET: corroborating hypometabolism in the same regions.
• Negative amyloid PET helps distinguish PPA-S from logopenic PPA of Alzheimer’s etiology.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Alzheimer Disease is characterized by early degeneration of the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex, leading to prominent anterograde episodic memory impairment. In contrast, Lewy Body Dementia features α-synuclein inclusions in cortical neurons, producing fluctuating cognition, recurrent visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. Understanding the distinct neurochemical deficits—cholinergic loss in AD versus both cholinergic and dopaminergic dysfunction in LBD—helps differentiate these syndromes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anterograde memory loss (D) is the hallmark of early AD due to tau-mediated neurofibrillary tangles and β-amyloid plaques in hippocampal circuits. The 2011 NIA-AA criteria emphasize insidious onset and progressive memory decline as core for probable AD (McKhann et al., 2011). By contrast, the 2017 Fourth Report of the DLB Consortium lists visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and cognitive fluctuations as core features of LBD, with memory relatively preserved initially (McKeith et al., 2017). Imaging studies (FDG-PET) show temporoparietal hypometabolism in AD versus occipital hypometabolism in LBD (Colloby et al., 2012), further supporting clinical differentiation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Staring into space for long periods
• Reflects cognitive fluctuations, a core feature of LBD.
• Misconception: “apathetic” appearance in AD vs true attentional waxing–waning in LBD.

B. Visual hallucinations
• Hallucinations are a core diagnostic criterion for LBD per DLB Consortium (McKeith et al., 2017).
• In AD, hallucinations occur late and are less frequent.

C. Parkinsonian motor features
• Early bradykinesia, rigidity, and gait instability point toward LBD or Parkinson’s disease dementia.
• AD may have extrapyramidal signs only in advanced stages or with medication side effects.

- In AD, confirm memory deficits with delayed recall testing (e.g., Hopkins Verbal Learning Test).
• A dopamine transporter SPECT scan (DaTscan) showing reduced striatal uptake supports LBD.
• Cholinesterase inhibitors benefit both AD and LBD, but extrapyramidal side effects limit LBD use of antipsychotics.

1. Equating any hallucination with AD—visual hallucinations are early and frequent in LBD.
2. Misattributing cognitive fluctuations to inattention in AD rather than true waxing–waning in LBD.

- McKhann GM et al., NIA-AA 2011 criteria: emphasize memory loss for probable AD (Level B evidence).
• McKeith IG et al., Fourth Report DLB Consortium 2017: define core LBD features, including visual hallucinations and fluctuations (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- AD: neurofibrillary tangles begin in entorhinal cortex → hippocampus → association cortices.
• LBD: α-synuclein aggregates in limbic and neocortical areas disrupt cholinergic and dopaminergic pathways.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Alzheimer’s disease commonly manifests not only with cognitive decline but also with Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms of Dementia (BPSD), including depression and agitation.
1. Depression in dementia often features low mood, insomnia, appetite change, and apathy—overlapping with neurodegeneration-induced alterations in serotonergic and noradrenergic circuits.
2. Agitation arises from limbic–prefrontal dysregulation, with increased amygdala reactivity and frontal inhibitory failure.
3. First-line pharmacotherapy for BPSD-related depression is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which enhance synaptic serotonin and can mitigate both mood and irritability.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Escitalopram (Cipralex) is an SSRI with high selectivity for the serotonin transporter, minimal cytochrome P450 interactions, and favorable tolerability in the elderly. The 2015 CitAD trial (Marano et al., JAMA) demonstrated that citalopram significantly reduced agitation scores in Alzheimer’s patients; escitalopram shares mechanistic benefits and has been shown to improve depressive symptoms and reduce irritability (Porsteinsson et al., Am J Geriatr Psychiatry 2014).
NICE Guideline CG42 (2018) and the American Psychiatric Association (2016) recommend SSRIs as first-line treatment for depression in dementia, with escitalopram preferred for its safety profile. Escitalopram’s once-daily dosing and low anticholinergic burden further support its use in polymedicated elderly patients.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Trazodone
– Primarily a 5-HT2A antagonist and α1‐adrenergic blocker used off-label for insomnia.
– Minimal antidepressant efficacy at low hypnotic doses; sedation may worsen daytime cognition and disinhibition.

C. Quetiapine
– Atypical antipsychotic indicated for psychosis and severe agitation.
– Black-box warning for increased mortality in dementia; risks of metabolic syndrome and extrapyramidal symptoms.

D. Rivastigmine
– Cholinesterase inhibitor targeting cognitive decline.
– No direct antidepressant or anti-agitation effect; may exacerbate gastrointestinal side effects and insomnia.

1. SSRIs are first-line for depression in Alzheimer’s disease; monitor for hyponatremia and QT prolongation, especially with citalopram.
2. Avoid routine use of antipsychotics for mild agitation due to mortality risk; reserve for severe, dangerous behaviors.
3. Titrate escitalopram slowly (start 5 mg daily) and reassess after 4–6 weeks for efficacy and tolerability.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine) for mild agitation—overlooks black-box warning and increased stroke risk.
2. Prescribing cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., rivastigmine) expecting mood improvement—these agents do not treat BPSD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- NICE CG42 (2018): Recommends SSRIs (e.g., sertraline, citalopram) as first-line for depression in dementia; consider escitalopram for safety (Level 1 evidence).
• APA Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Other Dementias (2016): Endorses SSRIs over TCAs or antipsychotics for depressive symptoms (Grade A).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Escitalopram selectively inhibits serotonin reuptake with minimal off-target effects. Starting dose: 5 mg daily, increase to 10–20 mg based on response. Monitor electrolytes and ECG in patients with cardiovascular comorbidities. Lower anticholinergic burden avoids exacerbation of cognitive impairment.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathophysiology centers on amyloid-β (Aβ) accumulation and tau hyperphosphorylation, leading to synaptic loss in hippocampus and association cortices. Early-onset familial AD (<5% of cases) arises from autosomal-dominant mutations in APP, PSEN1, or PSEN2, which alter Aβ processing. Late-onset AD (>65 years) is polygenic; the APOE ε4 allele is the strongest common genetic risk factor, influencing lipid transport, Aβ clearance, and neuroinflammation. Recognizing these distinctions guides genetic counseling, research enrollment, and interpretation of biomarker studies.

(125 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

APOE ε4 is the most prevalent genetic risk factor for late-onset AD, present in ~40% of patients versus ~15% of controls. Corder et al. (1993, Science) showed heterozygotes have a 3-fold increased risk, homozygotes up to 12-fold, with earlier onset by ~5–10 years. The 2018 NIA-AA Research Framework classifies APOE as a risk modifier, not a diagnostic criterion, emphasizing AT(N) biomarkers (amyloid, tau, neurodegeneration) for in vivo staging. In contrast, APP (chromosome 21), PSEN1, and PSEN2 encode γ-secretase components or its substrate, causing <1% of autosomal-dominant early-onset AD. Current AAN guidelines (2014 update) recommend targeted testing of PSEN1/2 and APP only in familial early-onset cases; APOE genotyping is discouraged for routine clinical diagnosis (Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. APP
• Why incorrect: Mutations in APP cause autosomal-dominant early-onset AD (<5% of cases), not the common late-onset form.
• Misconception: Assuming any amyloid pathway gene is the main risk factor.
• Differentiation: APP mutations alter Aβ cleavage sites, leading to overproduction of Aβ42 versus APOE ε4’s role in clearance.

C. PSEN1
• Why incorrect: PSEN1 mutations underlie aggressive familial early-onset AD (mean onset 30–50 years), rare in the general AD population.
• Misconception: Equating γ-secretase subunits with common risk alleles.
• Differentiation: PSEN1 variants show near-complete penetrance versus APOE ε4’s risk modification.

D. PSEN2
• Why incorrect: PSEN2 mutations are even rarer causes of familial early-onset AD with variable penetrance and later onset than PSEN1.
• Misconception: Overestimating the prevalence of presenilin mutations.
• Differentiation: PSEN2-related AD comprises <1% of cases, whereas APOE ε4 appears in >25% of late-onset patients.

Clinical Pearls

1. APOE ε4 carriers show greater amyloid PET uptake decades before clinical symptoms.
2. APOE ε2 is mildly protective; ε3 is neutral reference.
3. Routine APOE testing in asymptomatic individuals is not recommended due to limited predictive value and lack of disease-modifying prevention (ACMG guidelines).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking familial early-onset genes (APP, PSEN1/2) as the primary cause of most AD cases rather than rare autosomal-dominant variants.
2. Believing APOE ε4 is diagnostic rather than a risk factor—APOE status does not confirm or exclude AD without biomarker support.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. NIA-AA Research Framework (2018): Defines AD biologically via AT(N) criteria; advises APOE genotyping only for research, not routine clinical diagnosis (Expert consensus).
2. AAN Practice Guideline on Early-Onset Dementia (2014): Recommends genetic testing for APP, PSEN1, PSEN2 in familial early-onset cases; advises against APOE testing for clinical diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Hippocampal and entorhinal cortex atrophy on MRI correlates with early memory decline; PET imaging shows temporoparietal hypometabolism. APOE ε4 carriers demonstrate accelerated volume loss in these regions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- APP is cleaved by β- and γ-secretases into Aβ peptides; familial mutations increase the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio, promoting aggregation.
• APOE transports lipids and modulates Aβ clearance; the ε4 isoform binds Aβ less effectively, enhancing plaque deposition and neurotoxicity.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
APOE ε4 as the most common genetic risk factor for late-onset AD is frequently tested, often contrasted with APP/PSEN mutations in early-onset familial cases.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) and Alzheimer Disease (AD) share progressive cognitive decline but differ in core clinical manifestations.
• Lewy body pathology: alpha‐synuclein aggregates in cortical and subcortical neurons cause cholinergic and dopaminergic deficits.
• Cognitive fluctuations: transient variations in attention/arousal reflect subcortical involvement (thalamus, brainstem reticular formation).
• Visual hallucinations & parkinsonism: result from occipital hypometabolism and nigrostriatal dopaminergic loss, respectively.
• Anterograde memory: early and prominent in AD due to hippocampal neurofibrillary tangles and β‐amyloid plaques.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fluctuating cognition is the most sensitive and specific core feature distinguishing DLB from AD. The Fourth DLB Consortium Criteria (McKeith et al., 2017; updated 2020) designate cognitive fluctuations—defined as pronounced variations in attention and alertness—as a key diagnostic pillar (sensitivity ~85%, specificity ~80%). Recurrent well-formed visual hallucinations and spontaneous parkinsonism are also core features but may appear later or be confounded by medications. Anterograde episodic memory impairment is a hallmark of AD and can be present in DLB but is less pronounced early in the DLB course. Functional imaging (e.g., occipital hypometabolism on FDG‐PET, striatal dopamine transporter loss on ^123I-FP-CIT SPECT) further supports the clinical distinction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Visual hallucinations
• Incorrect because, although highly characteristic of DLB (specificity ~75%), they may occur in late‐stage AD or medication‐induced psychosis. Fluctuations remain more sensitive early indicators.

C. Parkinsonian motor features
• Incorrect as parkinsonism in DLB can be subtle early on; drug-induced parkinsonism may complicate AD. Moreover, clinical bradykinesia and rigidity lack the pronounced fluctuations seen in DLB cognitive state.

D. Anterograde memory impairment
• Incorrect because this is a primary feature of AD due to hippocampal atrophy; while DLB patients eventually develop memory deficits, early episodic memory is relatively preserved compared to AD.

Clinical Pearls

- Use the Clinician Assessment of Fluctuation (CAF) scale to quantify cognitive variability.
• Dopamine transporter imaging (DaTSCAN) has high positive predictive value for DLB when positive.
• DLB patients exhibit severe sensitivity to typical antipsychotics; quetiapine or clozapine preferred if needed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD)–related dream enactment for primary psychosis rather than an early DLB marker.
2. Overattributing parkinsonism to idiopathic Parkinson disease dementia instead of considering DLB when cognitive decline precedes or coincides.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Fourth DLB Consortium Criteria (McKeith et al., Alzheimer’s Dement. 2017;16:491–514; updated 2020): Reaffirm fluctuations as core diagnostic feature (Level A).
• AAN Practice Advisory on Dementia Diagnosis (AAN, 2021): Recommends dopamine transporter SPECT for differentiation of DLB vs AD when core clinical features are equivocal (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. DLB vs AD differentiation is frequently tested as scenario‐based vignettes, emphasizing core features—especially cognitive fluctuations—to guide examiners toward the diagnosis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) features cortical α-synuclein aggregation, especially affecting posterior cortices. FDG-PET measures regional glucose metabolism—areas of synaptic dysfunction appear hypometabolic. In DLB, the occipital lobes (primary visual cortex and visual association areas) show prominent hypometabolism, correlating with visuospatial impairment and visual hallucinations. By contrast, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) typically exhibits temporoparietal hypometabolism, and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) shows frontal hypometabolism. Identifying these distinct patterns on PET greatly enhances diagnostic accuracy and informs management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Occipital hypometabolism on FDG-PET is a supportive biomarker for probable DLB per the 2017 Fourth Consensus Report of the DLB Consortium (McKeith et al., 2017), with pooled sensitivity ~75% and specificity ~85%. Pathologically, Lewy bodies and cholinergic denervation in the occipital cortex reduce synaptic activity and glucose uptake. The “cingulate island sign” (relative sparing of posterior cingulate metabolism) further distinguishes DLB from AD. In contrast, AD shows bilateral temporoparietal hypometabolism (Johnson et al., 2014), and FTD demonstrates predominant frontal hypometabolism (Staffaroni et al., 2019). Current Movement Disorder Society criteria (2019) also endorse occipital hypometabolism on FDG-PET (Level B evidence) to differentiate DLB.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Frontal hypometabolism
• Incorrect: Frontal lobe hypometabolism is characteristic of FTD, not DLB.
• Misconception: Assuming all synucleinopathies begin in frontal lobes.
• Differentiator: FTD presents with behavioral changes and executive dysfunction.

C. Temporal hypometabolism
• Incorrect: Temporal lobe hypometabolism predominates in AD due to tau pathology.
• Misconception: Equating memory impairment in DLB with same PET pattern as AD.
• Differentiator: AD shows early episodic memory loss and temporoparietal deficits.

D. Parietal hypometabolism
• Incorrect: Parietal hypometabolism is also typical of AD, reflecting visuospatial and praxis deficits.
• Misconception: Overemphasizing parietal involvement in all dementias.
• Differentiator: In DLB, parietal changes are mild compared to occipital.
